revision.comment: Bot: fix deprecated Citation Style 1 parameters ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/NihlusBOT 9|Task 9]])
revision.text:
'''Circo Aereo''' is a circus group based in [[Finland]] and [[France]], under the direction of [[Maksim Komaro]], the artistic director, and [[Jani Nuutinen]], the artistic consultant.<ref name="byunews"> {{cite press release |title= Finnish contemporary circus Circo Aereo at BYU |publisher=Brigham Young University |date=February 15, 2011 |url= http://news.byu.edu/archive11-feb-circo.aspx |accessdate=September 14, 2011 }} </ref><ref name="george"> {{cite press release |title= Finnish circus ensemble Circo Aereo at George Mason University’s Center for the Arts |publisher=George Mason University |date= October 6, 2009 |url= http://cfa.gmu.edu/pressroom/382/ |accessdate=September 14, 2011 }} </ref> This group was established in 1996 as part of the “[[new circus]]” movement and travels frequently around the world.<ref name="ciraerpage"> {{cite web |url= http://www.circoaereo.net/fra/historia.html |title= Circo Aereo: Historique |publisher=Circo Aereo |location=Finland |language=French |trans-title=Circo Aereo:History |accessdate=September 14, 2011 }} </ref><ref name="byunews"/>
The circus is one of the most active Finnish group touring abroad, having appeared in theaters and in cultural festivals in about thirty countries.<ref name="byunews"/><ref name="ciraerpage"/> Circo Aereo has been called “a sparkling tribute to the circus” ([[Le Figaro]], France), “half circus, half cabaret” ([[Le Monde]], France) and “a treasure chest full of the things of which circus is made, filled with beautiful sights, meticulous joint efforts and inventive surprises” ([[Helsingin Sanomat]], Finland) .<ref name="byunews"/> Circo Aereo also has held workshops for schools and circus performers, along with other educational projects.<ref name="ciraerpage"/>
In order to develop the concept of the traditional circus, Circo Aereo incorporates other art forms into its shows, such as elements of theatre and dance, with audience interaction playing an important part. Super 8 was created in 2004, which combined traditional magic tricks, super 8 films and elements of video games. Trippo was also created in 2004 and geared for children, playing mostly in [[Scandinavia]]n countries and France.<ref name="ciraerpage"/>
In 2005, Circo Aereo created two musically dominant shows. The first was called the Louisiana Circus, co produced with the UMO Jazz Orchestra and in collaboration with [[Fritt Fall Rinne Radio]], a Finnish electro-jazz band. This production consisted of six artists and twenty musicians, combining circus with a cabaret atmosphere.<ref name="ciraerpage"/>
In 2007, an air show called “Piece for Two Ropes” opened, choreographed by [[Sanna Silvernnoinen]] and another show called FUR! by Maksim Komaro, both with the aim of combining contemporary circus and contemporary dance. In the latter production, artists from various countries, traditions and specialties created their own variations of traditional movements. Circo Aereo has worked with Sirque, pole circus Nexon in [[Limousin (province)|Limousin]] since 2007.<ref name="ciraerpage"/>
Circo Aereo’s most recent production is called “Espresso,” which is performed along with French juggling group [[Les Objets Volants]]. The show features four artists who create scenes and stories, on the ground and in the air, with juggling, dance and aerials, but no words.<ref name="byunews"/> According to director Maksim Komaro, Espresso is a journey through the history of circus, following Komaros own circus experience from the traditional to [[cabaret]] and the contemporary circus of Europe.<ref name="tourusa"> {{cite press release |title= Circo Aereo on tour in USA |publisher= Kulttuurivienti |location= Finland |date= October 1, 2009 |url= http://www.kulttuurivienti.fi/news.php?aid=15281 |accessdate= September 14, 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401010504/http://www.kulttuurivienti.fi/news.php?aid=15281 |archivedate= April 1, 2012 |df= }} </ref> Espresso is one of Circo Aereo's biggest successes.<ref name="wabash"> {{cite press release |title= The Circus is Coming to Town |publisher=Wabash College |date= February 24, 2011 |url= http://www.wabash.edu/news/displaystory.cfm?news_ID=8733 |accessdate=September 14, 2011 }} </ref> Helsingin Sanomat called the work “a treasure chest filled with beautiful sights, meticulous efforts and inventive surprises,” while Le Monde said, “intelligence and virtuosity are embedded in the magical vignettes.”<ref name="george"/>
The show was created in 2006, touring for three years in and around Europe especially in the [[Parc de la Villette]] in Paris, at the [[Théâtre de Vidy-Lausanne]] in [[Switzerland]] and the [[Damascus Opera House]], [[Syria]].<ref name="ciraerpage"/> In 2009, the show and the circus itself made its North American debut, performing eight eastern U.S. states. This tour was considered important to opening up the North American circus market to less-traditional shows.<ref name="tourusa"/><ref name="george"/> In 2011, Espresso and Circo Aereo returned to the continent to perform at [[Wabash College]] in [[Indiana]], [[Brigham Young University]] in [[Utah]] and the [[Festival Internacional Cervantino]] in [[Guanajuato, Guanajuato|Guanajuato]], [[Mexico]] .<ref name="wabash"/><ref name="fic"> {{cite web |url=http://www.festivalcervantino.gob.mx/Facebook/ArtistPivot |title=Circo Aereo & Les Objets Volants |publisher=Festival Internacional Cervantino |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |accessdate=September 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024193347/http://www.festivalcervantino.gob.mx/Facebook/ArtistPivot |archivedate=October 24, 2011 |df= }} </ref><ref name="byunews"/> ==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Circuses]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Dead Kansas | image =File:Dead Kansas Movie poster.png | caption =Movie Poster | creator = Rotten Productions | director = Aaron K. Carter | writer = [[Aaron K. Carter]]
[[Nicholas A. DeNicola]] | starring = [[Irwin Keyes]]
Joe McQueen
[[Ben Woolf]] [http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3333565/american-horror-story-actor-ben-woolf-passes-away-34/ Ben Woolf Dead Kansas] | music_by = | songs_by = | country = United States | language = English | network = [[YouTube]] | first_aired = September 6, 2012 | last_aired = October 17, 2013 | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 5[http://therottingzombie.blogspot.de/2015/01/dead-kansas-2012-zombie-horror-web.html Dead Kansas - appeared as a five-part web series] | executive_producer = | producer = Rotten Productions | editor = Trevor Penna | cinematography = | runtime = 64 minutes | website = }} '''''Dead Kansas''''' is a 2013 five-part [[webseries]], written, directed, and produced by Aaron K. Carter.[http://www.horrorsociety.com/2015/02/12/dead-kansas-review/ Dead Kansas (Review) | Horror Society] ==Plot== In a post-apocalyptic land consumed by ''Rottens'', a simple farmer and his teenage daughter struggle to survive. Meanwhile, an unruly gang make a plan to kidnap and sell the daughter for their own selfish profit. With the farmer/gang confrontation, a wicked tornado approaching, and "Rottens" everywhere - who will get out alive? ==Cast== * [[Irwin Keyes]] – Giant * [[Ben Woolf]] – Squeak[http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/90885/rest-peace-ben-woolf/ Ben Woolf had also appeared in Haunting Charles Manson, Dead Kansas ] * Joe McQueen – Skinny * Alexandria Lightford - Emma * Erin Miracle – Emma * Aaron Guerrero – Glenn * Michael Camp - Jebediah * Kevin Beardsley - Zeke / Rusty * Tony Della Catena – Leo * Darryl Dick – Doctor Emerson * [[Juliette Danielle]] – Rebecca ==Filming locations== Dead Kansas was filmed in [[Los Angeles, California]], primarily around the [[San Fernando Valley]].[https://www.facebook.com/deadkansas Dead Kansas Facebook Page] A portion was filmed at a circus-themed bar called, [[California Institute of Abnormalarts]]. It is located at 11334 Burbank Blvd, in [[North Hollywood, California]] 91601.[http://www.gorestruly.com/2015/01/08/slasher-shorts-dead-kansas/ Slasher Shorts: Dead Kansas] Every room is decorated with an eclectic assortment of ugly dolls, strange wall hangings, clowns, skeletons, and other spooky Halloween themed relics. CIA almost has a museum-like feel. Production was permitted only 4 hours to film there.[http://horrorunlimited.blogspot.de/2014/06/dead-kansas-award-winning-zombie-series.html 'Dead Kansas' ] ==Rottens== [[Zombies]] are referred to as "Rottens" in ''Dead Kansas''. There is only one physical zombie, in full make-up, towards the end of the film. The other Rottens are never shown. They are only simulated via Point Of View (POV) in black & white. The camera acted as the Rotten's eyes in certain shots, while the actors reacted. As tempting as it was to use traditional make-up and show the Rottens, the director specifically chose POV to do something different. Dead Kansas is the first zombie film to extensively use POV.[http://www.talentmonthly.com/112014_DEAD_KANSAS Dead Kansas - Talent Monthly Magazine] ==Release== The pilot of the webseries premiered on September 24, 2012 on [[YouTube]].[http://angryprincessslashes.blogspot.de/2014/05/aaron-carters-5-act-zombie-web-series.html Aaron Carters 5 act zombie web series Titled Dead Kansas] All five acts were eventually tied together and released on DVD as a full-length film in October 2013. The film version of the series, screened at the 2014 [[FANtastic Horror Film Festival]] - where it won an award for Best Zombie Film. Dead Kansas was released on [[Amazon Video]], February 26, 2015. ==Soundtrack== The punk-rock music heard throughout the film is from the band Power Of Aggression. They are from the Hollywood area and were active during 1999 through the early 2000's. The band was originally called Gauntlet in the early-90’s with former members Daniel Gallagher & Eddy Darbinian on guitars with Matthew Muller on bass guitar. The band eventually reformed in 1999, changed their name to Power of Aggression and adopted most of the songs from Gauntlet. Original member and chief-songwriter Anthony Robinson played lead guitar & vocals, Adam Ledezma played drums and Aaron K. Carter played bass guitar. When a soundtrack was needed, producers Aaron K. Carter and Adam Ledezma used the Power Of Aggression demo-tape that they recorded over a decade ago. The songs featured in Dead Kansas include: "The Ruler", "Walls Of Insanity", "Hate", "The Way We Feel", "Behold the Terror", and "Now". Composer Jonathan Price provided the rest of the music score. ==External links== *[http://deadkansas.com Official site] * {{IMDb title|2177336}} *[https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00U143XLI Amazon Video] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American zombie films]] [[Category:American web series]] [[Category:2013 web series endings]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox company | name = Ertl Company | logo = | type = | industry = [[Die-cast toy|Die-cast toys]] and scale models | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = {{Start date and age|1945}}
[[Dubuque, Iowa|Dubuque]], [[Iowa]], [[United States|U.S.]] | founder = Fred Ertl, Sr. | defunct = | hq_location_city = [[Dyersville, Iowa|Dyersville]], Iowa | hq_location_country = U.S. | area_served = | key_people = | products = | owner = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = | website = {{URL|ertl.com}} }} The '''Ertl Company''' is an American [[toy]] company best known for its [[Die-cast toy|die-cast]] metal alloy collectible replicas (or [[scale models]]) of [[farm equipment]] and vehicles. The company is based in Dyersville, Iowa, home of the [[National Farm Toy Museum]]. ==Plastic model kits== In the late 1970s, Ertl offered a series of plastic model kits of heavy commercial trucks, over-the-road trailers, tractors, plows, and farm wagons. Although these kits never achieved the hoped-for popularity, they led to the acquisition of [[Aluminum Metal Toys|AMT.]] In 1983, AMT was purchased by Ertl from Lesney, and renamed AMT/Ertl. AMT/Ertl then had a 24-year relationship until AMT was sold in 2007. ==American muscle diecast== In the early 1990s Ertl started the American Muscle line up of diecast collectible cars and trucks. These were 1:18 scale replicas that quickly found a dedicated following of baby boomers. Limited editions of 2,500 were especially sought after. Many of the earliest releases have fetched upwards of $500.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} The most popular and desirable is the [[1957 Chevrolet|1957 Chevy]] [[Chevrolet Bel Air|Bel Air]] known as Peggy Sue.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} ==Die cast [[Airplane model|airplanes]]== Ertl has also produced a number of die cast airplane models over the years, including some promotional items for [[Texaco]],http://www.3000toys.com/catalog/products.aspx?MFG=ERTL&ORDER=M&TYPE=Aircraft&setup= [[Continental Airlines]]{{cite web|title=Continental Airlines DC-3 by Ertl F154 with stand|website=Randy's Diecast|url=http://randysdiecast.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=13&products_id=1021&zenid=04f2a0269dde30ead5d937caf1f6dac0|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20150702105139/http://randysdiecast.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=13&products_id=1021 |archivedate=July 2, 2015}} and others. ==History== Ertl has been producing farm toy replicas since 1945. For over 60 years, the company has produced farm toys for industry brands such as: [[John Deere]], [[Case IH]], [[New Holland Ag|New Holland]], and [[AGCO]]. Ertl has also, on different occasions, acquired the licenses to produce die-cast vehicles and [[figurine]]s as well as [[scale model|model kits]] for [[Looney Tunes]], [[Garfield]], [[Thomas the Tank Engine]], [[Tugs (TV series)]], [[Super Mario Bros (film)|Super Mario Bros.]] [[DC Comics]], and [[Star Wars]]. In 1999, Ertl was purchased by [[Racing Champions]]. Ertl is currently a brand under the [[RC2 Corporation]] umbrella. Important Dates in Racing Champions/Ertl Company History{{cite web|title=RC2 Company Information - The Ertl Company|url=http://www.rcertl.com/history.asp|accessdate=2011-09-08|archive-url=http://archive.is/cLSP|archive-date=September 9, 2012}} *1945 - The Ertl Company is founded by Fred Ertl, Sr., in Dubuque, Iowa. *1959 - The company moves to larger facilities in Dyersville, Iowa. *1967 - Ertl is acquired by [[Victor Comptometer|Victor Comptometer Corporation]]. *1971 - Ertl acquires Carter Tru-Scale. *1973 - Ertl begins manufacturing plastic model kits. *1974 - Ertl acquires Structo Stamped Steel. *1977 - [[Kidde]], Inc. acquires Ertl with purchase of Victor Comptometer Corp. *1981 - Ertl acquires [[Aluminum Metal Toys|AMT model kit company]]. *1985 - Ertl acquires MPC model kits. *1987 - [[Hanson plc]] purchases Kidde. Ertl acquires [[ESCI]] model kit company. *1989 - Racing Champions is founded by Bob Dods, Boyd Meyer and Peter Chung. *1990 - Ertl releases the first Precision Series farm toy replica. *1991-92 - Racing Champions obtains [[NASCAR]] license *1992 - Fred Ertl, Jr. & Robert J. Ertl retire. *1995 - Hanson plc consolidates its U.S. companies to form U.S.I. (United States Industries). *1993- Ertl begins the Wing Of Texaco die cast airplane collection *1996 - Racing Champions introduces its Mint line of non-racing vehicles. Racing Champions Corporation is formed. *1997 - Racing Champions completes its initial public stock offering (RACN on NASDAQ). *1999 - Company produces a commercial version of the [[Eternity puzzle]] *1999 - Racing Champions acquires The Ertl Company. *2000 - Ertl acquires [[Britains Limited]] *2003 - Racing Champions Ertl acquired Chicago-based [[Learning Curve International]], Inc. *2004 - [[RC2 Corporation]] acquired [[Playing Mantis]] assets and [[The First Years]] Inc., *2008 - Tomy acquired RC2; maintains control of Ertl, Racing Champions and Johnny Lightning tooling *2008 - Auto World (a division of Round 2, LLC) signs licensing agreement to produce and market AMT, MPC, Polar Lights, and 24 and 18 scale diecast, and access to Racing Champions and Johnny Lightning tooling *2009 - Ertl celebrates 50 years in Dyersville, IA *2010 - Ertl celebrates its 65th Anniversary. ==See also== {{Portal|Companies}} * [[Bumble Ball]] * [[Hot Wheels]] * [[Jada Toys]] * [[Maisto]] * [[Matchbox (toy company)]] * [[Thomas & Friends merchandise #Ertl Company]] * [[Tomica]] * [[Welly (toy company)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ertl.com Ertl website] * [http://www.rc2.com RC2 Corporation website] [[Category:Ertl Company| ]] [[Category:Toy companies of the United States]] [[Category:Toy cars and trucks]] [[Category:Die-cast toys]] [[Category:Companies based in Iowa]] [[Category:Toy brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1945]] [[Category:Model manufacturers]] [[Category:Dyersville, Iowa]]

{{for|the American basketball and football coach|Eugene Lambert (coach)}} {{Infobox person | name = Eugene Lambert | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1928<ref name="RTÉ 23 Feb 10" /> | birth_place = [[County Sligo]], [[Ireland]] | death_date = {{death-date and age|23 February 2010|1928}} | death_place = [[Monkstown, County Dublin|Monkstown]], [[County Dublin]], [[Ireland]] | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | other_names = | known_for = His puppetry, ''[[Wanderly Wagon]]'' | occupation = Puppeteer }}
'''Eugene Lambert''' (1928<ref name="RTÉ 23 Feb 10" /> – 22 February 2010)<ref name="Irish Times 25 Feb 10">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/features/2010/0224/1224265087068.html|title=The father of puppetry in Ireland|author=Fiona McCann|date=24 February 2010|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=The Irish Times Trust|accessdate=25 February 2010}}</ref> was an [[Irish people|Irish]] [[puppeteer]] and [[actor]] from [[County Sligo]]. He was owner of the [[Lambert Puppet Theatre]] in [[Monkstown, County Dublin]]. He was noted for co-starring as O'Brien in the [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] television series ''[[Wanderly Wagon]]''. Lambert's Puppet Theatre also produced the iconic children's television character [[Bosco (TV series)|Bosco]]. He died in 2010 at the age of 81.
==Early life== Lambert was born and raised in [[County Sligo]].<ref name="Belfast Telegraph 23 Feb 2010">{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/uk-ireland/puppeteer-eugene-lambert-dies-at-81-14694353.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130420050741/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/uk-ireland/puppeteer-eugene-lambert-dies-at-81-14694353.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 April 2013 |title=Puppeteer Eugene Lambert dies at 81 |date=23 February 2010 |newspaper=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media]] |accessdate=25 February 2010 }}</ref> His father was the county librarian, but died at the age of 35.<ref name="indo-obit">{{cite web | url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/a-showman-who-kept-a-generation-entertained-26635249.html | title=A showman who kept a generation entertained | publisher=[[Irish Independent]] | date=24 February 2010 | accessdate=15 January 2014 | author=O'Shea, Joe}}</ref> His mother took on his father's old job and Lambert was raised in a bookish home.<ref name="indo-obit"/> He made his first puppet aged 8 and was a proficient ventriloquist by the time he reached his early teens.<ref name="indo-obit"/>
==Career== Lambert was long a stalwart of the Irish [[vaudeville]] scene, particularly in Dublin, although he also toured the country frequently with his wife Mai. His most common acts were with Finnegan, a mischievous storyteller, and Judge, a pensive dog. With the rise of television in the 1960s, the Lambert puppet theatre became a fixture in Irish broadcasting. In the early 1960s, Lambert devised a puppet series for children entitled ''Murphy agus a Chairde'' ("Murphy and His Friends"). Murphy was a giant who lived in a magical kingdom. Its king, "An Rí", only had one problem - constant mischief from two witches, Feemy and Babóg. [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] was the only station most people in Ireland could then access and Murphy's adventures were soon an important part of most children's viewing. Murphy himself appeared as the in-vision continuity announcer all through one of RTÉ's Christmas Day broadcasts.
In November 1963, Lambert drew international attention after he successfully acquired a driver's license for his puppet Finnegan. Lambert reported that he did so simply to show how easy it was for anybody in Ireland to obtain a license.
He later co-starred in the children's television series ''[[Wanderly Wagon]]'' as the mischievous and greedy O'Brien, known for his childlike curiosity and cowardice in the face of magical events. Lambert and his family provided many regular (puppet) characters — Judge the dog, Mr Crow (who lived in a cuckoo clock), the mysterious Foxy Loxy, and the untrustworthy Ssneaky Ssnake.<ref name="indo-obit-2">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/puppeteer-leaves-a-loving-legacy-of-laughter-2076416.html|title=Puppeteer leaves a loving legacy of laughter|author=Jason O'Brien|date=24 February 2010|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=25 February 2010}}</ref> The series also featured Irish actor [[Frank Kelly]] who played Dr Astro in the series, who later appeared as Fr. Jack Hackett in ''[[Father Ted]]''.
Another series created by Eugene Lambert was adapted from a children's book by [[Patricia Lynch]], ''Brógeen Follows The Magic Tune.'' Brógeen was a leprechaun who teamed up with a fiddler who had heard a piece of music created by the fairies - and they wanted it back. The series was a great success and won several awards internationally. Some years later, when Lambert enquired about the 2" master video tapes, RTÉ admitted to having re-used them. ''Brogeen'' (and most of ''Wanderly Wagon'') was gone forever, although a dubbed version of ''Brogeen'' still exists in the archives of [[NRK]].
==Lambert Puppet Theatre and Museum== The [[Lambert Puppet Theatre]] was established in 1972. Eugene Lambert founder and Director of the Lambert Puppet Theatre had an interest in puppetry from a very early age, making his own ventriloquist dummy Charley, which later developed into Finnegan the ventriloquist act. In the early years with Finnegan, Eugene toured UK and Ireland extensively and in later years he promoted Ireland for Irish Tourist Board, touring USA, Japan and Australia.<ref name="J O'S Irish Inde 24 Feb 2010">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/a-showman-who-kept-a-generation-entertained-2076362.html|title=A showman who kept a generation entertained|author=[[Joe O'Shea]]|date=24 February 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=25 February 2010}}</ref>
Lambert's Puppet Theatre was responsible for producing the popular 1980s children's television character [[Bosco (TV series)|Bosco]] who was an ever-present fixture on the Irish national station.
Eugene and Mai Lambert had ten children two of whom predeceased him.<ref name="J O'S Irish Inde 24 Feb 2010" /> Lambert supplemented his day job as refrigeration engineer with his "[[Punch and Judy]]",<ref>{{cite video|people=Conor Hunt |date=23 February 2010 |title=Death of Eugene Lambert: News report |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0223/lamberte_av.html?2707083,null,230 |medium=News report |publisher=''[[RTÉ News and Current Affairs|RTÉ News]]'' |accessdate=25 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605142808/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0223/lamberte_av.html?2707083%2Cnull%2C230 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> appearing in private houses and night time was taken up with appearing with his vent act Finnegan at Gala concerts and Dinners. The Lambert family participated in Jury’s Irish Cabaret for 7 years bringing topical puppet acts to the American audience.
Eugene and his wife Mai visited The Harlequin Puppet Theatre in [[Colwyn Bay]], [[Wales]] and an International Puppet Festival in [[Prague]]. Inspired, they decided to open a puppet theatre of their own, ''The Lambert Puppet Theatre''.
==Death== Lambert died at his home in Monkstown, County Dublin on Monday 22 February 2010, aged 82.<ref name="RTÉ 23 Feb 10">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0223/lamberte.html|title=Eugene Lambert dies aged 82|date=23 February 2010|work=[[RTÉ News and Current Affairs|RTÉ News]]|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]|accessdate=23 February 2010}}</ref><ref name="Irish Times 23 Feb 10">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0223/breaking8.html?via=mr|title=Puppeteer Eugene Lambert dies aged 82|date=23 February 2010|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=The Irish Times Trust|accessdate=23 February 2010}}</ref> His funeral on 26 February 2010 was attended by entertainers and politicians, with [[Liam Ó Maonlaí]] and [[Sinéad O'Connor]] singing at his [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] and a miniature Wanderly Wagon featuring in the ceremony.<ref name="RTÉ 26 Feb 10">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0226/lamberte.html|title=Eugene Lambert laid to rest|date=26 February 2010|work=[[RTÉ News and Current Affairs|RTÉ News]]|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]|accessdate=26 February 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080112090228/http://www.fustar.info/2006/02/08/92/ Eugene Lambert interview with fustar.info (1/3)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080618183507/http://lambertp.ipower.com/lambert/home/index.htm Eugene Lambert profile]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lambert, Eugene}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:People from County Dublin]] [[Category:People from County Sligo]] [[Category:Puppeteers]] [[Category:Ventriloquists]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Fred Karno | image = fredkarno.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Frederick John Westcott | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1866|03|26}} | birth_place = [[Exeter]], [[Devon]], England | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1941|09|18|1866|03|26}} | death_place = [[Lilliput, Dorset]], England | other_names = | occupation = Theatre impresario of [[music hall]] | known_for = [[Slapstick]], notable comedians who worked for his company include [[Charlie Chaplin]] and [[Stan Laurel]] | spouse = | website = }}
'''Frederick John Westcott''' (26 March 1866 – 18 September 1941), best known by his stage name '''Fred Karno''', was an English [[theatre]] [[impresario]] of the British [[music hall]].<ref name=up/> As a comedian of [[slapstick]] he is credited with popularizing the [[Pieing|custard-pie-in-the-face gag]].<ref>Leslie Halliwell, John Walker (2001). "Halliwell's Who's who in the Movies". p. 240. HarperCollinsEntertainment, 2001</ref> During the 1890s, in order to circumvent stage censorship, Karno developed a form of sketch comedy without dialogue.
Cheeky authority-defying playlets such as ''Jail Mum'' (1896) in which prisoners play tricks on warders and ''Early Birds'' (1903), where a small man defeats a large ruffian in London's East End, can be seen as precursors of movie silent comedy. Film producer [[Hal Roach]] stated: "Fred Karno is not only a genius, he is the man who originated slapstick comedy. We in Hollywood owe much to him."<ref>J. P. Gallagher (1971). "Fred Karno: master of mirth and tears". p. 165. Hale.</ref>
Among the music hall [[comedian]]s who worked for him were [[Charlie Chaplin]] and his [[understudy]], Arthur Jefferson, who later adopted the name of [[Stan Laurel]]. These were part of what was known as "Fred Karno's Army", a phrase still occasionally used in the UK to refer to a chaotic group or organisation. The phrase was also adapted by British soldiers into a [[war song|trench song]] in the [[First World War]], as a [[parody]] of, or rather to the tune of, the [[hymn]] "[[The Church's One Foundation]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oucs.ox.ac.uk/ww1lit/education/tutorials/intro/trench/songs.html#fred |title='Trench Songs', The First World War Poetry Digital Archive |accessdate=16 October 2010|quote=We are Fred Karno's army, we are the ragtime infantry. We cannot fight, we cannot shoot, what bleeding use are we? And when we get to Berlin we'll hear the Kaiser say, "Hoch, hoch! Mein Gott, what a bloody rotten lot, are the ragtime infantry" |publisher=[[University of Oxford]] }}</ref> In the [[Second World War]] it was adapted as the Anthem of the [[Guinea Pig Club]], the first line becoming "We are McIndoe's Army ...".
==Biography== Karno was born in [[Exeter]], [[Devon]], England, in 1866. He worked as a cabinet maker with a workshop in Waterbeer Street. He married Edith and in 1896 his son, Fred Karno Jr. was born.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Fred Karno, Jr. |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0B11F934551B728DDDAD0894DA405B818AF1D3 |quote=Fred Karno, Jr., British comedian, died at his home today in Marg'ate, Kent. He was 69 years old. Mr. Karno, as a young man, appeared in "Humming Birds," one;... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=4 February 1961 |accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref> In 1904 he visited [[Tagg's Island]] on London's [[River Thames]] and in 1912 he bought the island and the existing hotel. He demolished the original hotel and hired architect [[Frank Matcham]] to build [[The Karsino]].<ref name=thames>{{cite web |url=http://www.richmond.gov.uk/home/leisure_and_culture/local_history_and_heritage/local_studies_collection/local_history_notes/fred_karno_and_the_karsino.htm |title=Fred Karno and the Karsino |accessdate=16 October 2010 |publisher=[[Richmond upon Thames]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110417024358/http://www.richmond.gov.uk/home/leisure_and_culture/local_history_and_heritage/local_studies_collection/local_history_notes/fred_karno_and_the_karsino.htm |archivedate=17 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> With the advent of [[Film|cinema]], the music hall's popularity declined. As a result of this decline, Karno went [[bankrupt]] in 1925.<ref name=thames/>
On 24 May 1927 his wife Edith, from whom he had been separated since 1904, died in her sleep of [[diabetes]]. Three weeks later, Karno married his second wife, his long-time partner, Marie Moore. Karno went to the US in 1929, and was hired by the [[Hal Roach Studios]] as a writer-director, and was reunited with one of his former protégés, [[Stan Laurel]]. However, his stay at the studio was brief and unsuccessful as [[Hal Roach]] found out Karno's main abilities were as a producer, and he departed in February 1930. On his return to Britain, Karno helped to write and produce several short films and in 1936 returned to the theatre with a show called ''Real Life''.<ref>Book-Stan and Ollie: The Roots of Comedy (Faber and Faber Ltd.) Author-Simon Louvish. Publishing Date-2001.</ref>
Karno spent his last years in southwest England in the village of [[Lilliput, Dorset]], as a part-owner of an off-licence bought with financial help from Charlie Chaplin,<ref name="chaplin">{{cite web| title=Filming City Lights| url=http://www.charliechaplin.com/biography/articles/4-City-Lights| publisher=CharlieChaplin.com| author=David Robinson| year=2004| accessdate=12 May 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122062524/http://charliechaplin.com/biography/articles/4-City-Lights| archivedate=22 November 2010| df=dmy-all}}</ref> and died there in 1941 from diabetes, aged 75.<ref name=up>{{cite news|title=Fred Karno|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1941/09/19/archives/fred-karno.html|work=[[United Press]] in the [[New York Times]]|page=23|date=19 September 1941|quote=Westcott, an old-time comedian and veteran of the English vaudeville circuit known to show business as Fred Karno, died yesterday |accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref><ref name=thames/>
==Legacy== [[File:Astoria (Péniche).jpg|right|thumb|Karno's ''[[Astoria (recording studio)|Astoria]]'' houseboat from the river]] His [[houseboat]], the ''[[Astoria (recording studio)|Astoria]]'', on the [[River Thames]] at [[Hampton, London|Hampton]], [[Middlesex]], is now used as a [[recording studio]] by [[Pink Floyd]]'s [[David Gilmour]].<ref>Winn, p. 141</ref>
On 30 September 2012, the [[Music Hall Guild of Great Britain and America]] unveiled a commemorative [[blue plaque]] to Karno at his former studios at 38 Southwell Road, [[Camberwell]], in south London.<ref>[http://www.themusichallguild.com/news.php "Fred Karno Commemorated"], The Music Hall Guild of Great Britain and America, accessed 30 September 2012</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite web|first=Eric|last=Midwinter|title=Karno, Fred (1866–1941)|work=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|orig-year=First published 2004|date=January 2011|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/37623|accessdate=5 December 2009}}(Subscription required.) *{{cite news|title=Death of Fred Karno|work=The Times|date=19 September 1941}} (Available through [http://archive.timesonline.co.uk/tol/archive/ The Times archive]. Subscription required.) *{{cite news|first=Derek|last=Farnes|title=Fred Karno: Immortal Comic Who Recruited Laughter|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_EISAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gLoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5517,11605&dq=fred-karno&hl=en|work=The Age|page=2|date=1 July 1950|accessdate=5 December 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} *{{cite book | last= Winn| first=Christopher | year=2010| title=I Never Knew That About the River Thames| location=London | publisher=Ebury Press | isbn=978-0-09-193357-9}} {{Refend}}

[[Image:Gail Kane 1917.jpg|Gail Kane|thumb]] [[File:Souls in Pawn.jpg|thumb|''Souls in Pawn'' (1917)]] '''Gail Kane''' (born '''Abigail Kane''', July 10, 1885 – February 17, 1966) was an American stage and [[silent movie]] actress
==Early years== Kane was born in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. She attended a private school in [[Newburgh, New York]], but eschewed additional education to become an actress. She became a dedicated student of the art of [[pantomime]]. She stood 5'7" tall, weighed 142 pounds, and had dark brown hair and eyes.
==Theatrical actress== Kane performed at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]] in ''Heap Game Watch'' in January 1914. She had a significant role in ''Seven Keys To Baldpate Astor'', which was staged at the [[Gaiety Theatre, London]], in May 1914. The comedy was brought to the stage by [[George M. Cohan]]. She paired with George Nash in ''The Miracle Man'' at the [[Astor Theatre, New York City|Astor Theatre]]. The play was produced on [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] in the fall of 1914.
<!--[[Image:GailKane.jpg|thumb|Gail Kane {{deletable image-caption|Friday, 4 December 2009}}]]--> Kane acted in a presentation of ''The Hyphen Knickerbocker'' in April 1915. She returned to the stage at the [[Broadhurst Theatre]] in July 1920. She was paired with [[Earle Fox]], another actor who had been spending much of his time in movies. They appeared in the comedy ''Come Seven''. The production was an adaptation by [[Octavus Roy Cohen]] of stories he had contributed to ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]''. The play was the first ever featuring an entirely [[Caucasian race|caucasian]] cast in [[black face]].
''Lawful Larceny'' (1922) was a comedy adapted from the writing of Samuel Shipman. It was presented at the Republic Theater, built by [[Oscar Hammerstein I|Oscar Hammerstein]] in 1900, at [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]]. The players included Kane, [[Margaret Lawrence (actress)|Margaret Lawrence]], Ida Waterman, and [[Lowell Sherman]].
''The Breaking Point'' by [[Mary Roberts Rinehart]] was staged at the [[Klaw Theatre]], West 45th Street, [[New York City]], in August 1923. The plot concerned [[amnesia]] with the [[setting (fiction)]] moving from New York to [[Wyoming]] and back. Kane, Regina Wallace, [[Reginald Barlow]], and McKay Morris were the principal actors in the drama.
She played Ellen Halpin in the 1925 comedy ''[[Loggerheads (play)|Loggerheads]]'' at the [[Cherry Lane Theatre]]. The [[Booth Theatre]] produced ''Paid'', written by Sam Forrest, in November 1925. Kane portrayed ''Mrs John Ramsey'' in a play which endured for twenty-one performances.
==Arrest== Kane was arrested following a performance of ''The Captive'' at the [[Empire Theatre (41st Street)|Empire Theater]] on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] in February 1927. The production was considered indecent and a violation of Section 1140A of the New York City Criminal Code, although the play had been tried and acquitted of immorality a short time earlier by a citizen's play jury. It was in its fifth month of production.
Forty-one arrests were made in total. Two other productions were raided on the same night. They were ''Sex'', playing at Daly's 63rd St. Theater, and ''The Virgin Man'', which was being performed before an audience at the Princess Theater. Among the actors taken to Night Court were [[Basil Rathbone]], [[Helen Menken]], Ann Trevor, Winifred Fraser, John Miltern, and Arthur Lewis. Menken was comforted by Kane as she made her exit after becoming agitated by the glares and explosions of cameras snapping as she stepped out on the sidewalk. "Please make them stop," Menken reportedly exclaimed. Also arrested was [[Mae West]], the star of ''Sex'', and twenty others among a cast of fifty. Authorities promised to repeat the arrests if the plays were not withdrawn or modified to comply with the criminal code.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1927/02/10/archives/police-raid-three-shows-sex-captives-and-virgin-man-hold-actors-and.html|title=POLICE RAID THREE SHOWS, SEX, CAPTIVES AND VIRGIN MAN; HOLD ACTORS AND MANAGERS; ALL GO TO NIGHT COURT Police Politely Serve the Warrants After the Final Curtains. VICTIMS NOT UNWILLING Submit Cordially to Arrests, Which Will Be Repeated Till Plays Are Purged. 41 ARE RELEASED IN BAIL Two Shows Had Been Cleared by the Play Jury -- Drive May Be Extended to Others.|accessdate=15 January 2016|agency=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|date=Feb 10, 1927}}</ref>
==Movie career== Kane's movie career spanned much of the silent era, beginning with a role as ''Bonita Canby'', in ''Arizona'' (1913). In the western she had the third lead, portraying the unfaithful wife of a [[U.S. Cavalry]] officer. She co-starred as Jurgis Rudkus's (played by George Nash) wife Ona Lukoszaite in the film adaptation of [[Upton Sinclair]]'s ''[[The Jungle (1914 film)|The Jungle]]'' (1914). She starred in ''Via Wireless'' (1915) which was adapted from a play by [[Winchell Smith]] and Paul Armstrong. The story describes the competition between two men in the invention of a new naval gun. A wealthy man becomes the rival of one of the inventors for the affection of the daughter of an [[ironmaster]]. As ''Frances Durant'', Kane is finally given a part worthy of her skill as an actress. One critic described her as ''a diamond set in brass'' in her previous films. {{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
[[File:Gail Kane 1923 Income Letter.jpg|thumb|right|Letter from Inspiration Pictures Inc. informing Gail Kane of her 1923 earnings for [[The White Sister (1923 film)|The White Sister]]']] Kane was employed by the [[Mutual Film Corporation]] of [[Santa Barbara, California]] when she made ''The Upper Crust'' (1917). Produced by Mutual-American, Edward Pell is cast as Kane's [[leading man]] in a comedy replete with humor. Kane is a young [[Irish people|Irish]] woman named ''Molly O'Toole''. She impersonates a wealthy [[dowager]] and succeeds in her [[deception|ruse]] long enough to enjoy herself and eventually marry the dowager's son.
In July 1917 Kane joined an effort organized by William A. Brady, President of the National Association of the Motion Picture Industry, and [[D.W. Griffith]]. Their task was to utilize film as a tool of information regarding the ''plans and purposes'' of the [[United States]] in [[World War I]]. Brady was appointed by President [[Woodrow Wilson]] to mobilize the motion-picture industry. Kane was assigned to the Food Commission. In addition to Mutual she was associated with [[Metro Pictures]], [[Pathé]], and World. Kane filed a suit against Mutual in 1918, asking $33,500 for alleged [[breach of contract]]. {{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
''The Scarlet Oath'' (1917) was a challenging movie for Kane who played the dual role of two women. ''A Game of Wits'' (1917) is a five-reel comedy with Kane portraying ''Jeannette Browning'' in a unique love story.
She continued to act in motion pictures for another decade. Among her later movies are ''Love's Law'' (1918), ''The Daredevil'' (1918), ''Someone Must Pay'' (1919), ''Romeo's Dad'' (1919), ''Empty Arms'' (1920), ''Idle Hands'' (1921), ''[[The White Sister (1923 film)|The White Sister]]'' (1923), and ''Convoy'' (1927).
==Marriage== Kane's husband, Henry Iden Ottman, died in January 1939. Ottman was born in New York City in 1880, the son of William Ottman and Christine Iden. Ottman moved to [[Augusta, Maine]] in 1921. Kane and Ottman had a son, William Kane Ottman.
==Private life== She owned a collection of [[Scarab (artifact)|scarab]] beetles considered to be one of the finest in America in 1917. The most valuable of the [[Scarabaeus sacer]] is said to have been removed from the tomb of an [[Ptolemaic Egypt|Egyptian]] princess of the 2nd [[Ptolemaic dynasty]]. Archaeologists believe it to be one of a number issued to illustrate the doctrine of the resurrection. Kane was given her first scarab by [[Howard Estabrook]], who played ''Adhemar de Gratignan'' in ''Divorcons'' (1913). Presented at the New York Playhouse, Kane portrayed ''Mme. de Brionne'' in the play written by the [[France|French]] dramatist [[Victorien Sardou]]. Estabrook purchased the scarab in [[India]] while he was touring. {{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
She collected bathing suits. Kane possessed one of the most attractive collections of one-piece, two-piece, and ''fluffy ruffles seashore outfits'' in [[Chicago, Illinois]] by 1917. Each bathing suit was also designed by her.
==Death== Gail Kane died in [[Augusta, Maine]] in 1966, aged 80.
==Filmography== *''[[Arizona (1913 film)|Arizona]]'' (1913) *''The Great Diamond Robbery'' (1914) *''[[The Jungle (1914 film)|The Jungle]]'' (1914) *''Dan'' (1914) *''The Pit'' (1914) *''[[Her Great Match]]'' (1915) *''Via Wireless'' (1915) *''The Labyrinth'' (1915) *''Paying the Price'' (1916) *''[[The Velvet Paw]]'' (1916) *''The Scarlet Oath'' (1916) *''The Heart of a Hero'' (1916) *''The Men She Married'' (1916) *''[[On Dangerous Ground (1917 film)|On Dangerous Ground]]'' (1917) *''The Red Woman'' (1917) *''As Man Made Her'' (1917) *''Whose Wife?'' (1917) *''[[The Serpent's Tooth (1917 film)|The Serpent's Tooth]]'' (1917) *''The False Friend'' (1917) *''The Upper Crust'' (1917) *''[[Souls in Pawn]]'' (1917) *''The Bride's Silence'' (1917) *''Southern Pride'' (1917) *''A Game of Wits'' (1917) *''When Men Betray'' (1918) *''Love's Law'' (1918) *''The Daredevil'' (1918) *''Someone Must Pay'' (1919) *''Romeo's Dad'' (1919) (*short) *''Empty Arms'' (1920) *''Idle Hands'' (1921) *''Wise Husbands'' (1921) *''[[The White Sister (1923 film)|The White Sister]]'' (1923) *''[[Convoy (1927 film)|Convoy]]'' (1927)

{{Infobox film | name = Generation Iron 2 | image = | alt = | caption = Theatrical Poster | director = [[Vlad Yudin]] | producer = Vlad Yudin
Edwin Mejia | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Kai Greene]] * [[Calum von Moger]] * [[Rich Piana]] * [[Iris Kyle]] }} | editing = Matthew Adams | language = English | border = yes }} '''''Generation Iron 2''''' is a 2017 [[documentary film]] and sequel to ''[[Generation Iron]]''. The film follows the next generation of bodybuilders as the industry opens up to viral internet stars as well as younger bodybuilders pushing the limits of how massive the human physique can become. The film features [[Kai Greene]], [[Calum Von Moger]], [[Rich Piana]], and [[Flex Wheeler]], among other athletes.{{Cite web|url=http://generationiron.com/watch-official-full-length-teaser-trailer-generation-iron-2/|title=WATCH: Official Full Length Teaser Trailer For Generation Iron 2|last=Team|first=GI|website=generationiron.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-16}}[http://muscle-insider.com/news/generation-iron-2-coming-2017 Generation Iron 2 Coming in 2017] ''Generation Iron 2'' was released in limited theatrical, DVD, and Video On Demand on May 12, 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.musculardevelopment.com/news/bodybuilding-news/15982-generation-iron-2-to-release-in-theaters-dvd-and-on-demand-may-12th.html#.WRCiDvnyuM8|title=‘Generation Iron 2’ to Release in Theaters, DVD and On Demand May 12th|last=childers|first=nate|website=www.musculardevelopment.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-05-08}}{{Citation|title=Generation Iron 2: Trailer 1|url=http://www.fandango.com/generationiron2_200869/movieoverview|language=en|accessdate=2017-05-08}} == Cast == * [[Kai Greene]] * [[Calum von Moger]] * [[Rich Piana]] * [[Iris Kyle]] * [[Flex Wheeler]] * [[Mamdouh Elssbiay]] * [[Hidetada Yamagishi]] * [[Brandon Curry]] * [[Dana Linn Bailey]] == Synopsis == ''Generation Iron 2'' is the sequel to the 2013 documentary film ''[[Generation Iron]]''. The follow up film, directed by [[Vlad Yudin]], follows the top five bodybuilding and fitness mega-stars on the journey to build the ultimate physique. Exploring the world of social media and internet, the film depicts how the rules have changed as to what makes a successful "mass monster" bodybuilder. A new generation, new bodybuilders, new world, and new people carve their own path to physique perfection.[http://www.whosay.com/articles/16506-generation-iron-2-video 'Generation Iron 2': How Social Media Took Over Bodybuilding and the Fitness Industry] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about bodybuilding]] [[Category:Sequel films]] {{sport-documentary-film-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = George H. Coes | image = George_Coes.jpg | caption = George H. Coes | image_size = 80px | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_place = | birth_date = 1828 | death_place = | death_date = March 16, 1897 | origin = [[Providence, Rhode Island]] | instrument = [[banjo]] | genre = [[Minstrel show]] | occupation = | years_active = 1852–1889 | label = | associated_acts = [[Luke Schoolcraft]] | website = | current_members = | past_members = }}
'''George H. Coes''' (1828 – March 16, 1897) was an American [[Minstrel show|minstrel music]] performer. He appeared in numerous minstrel shows in [[California]] and throughout the [[Northeastern United States]].
==Early life== Coes was born in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] in 1828.
==Career in minstrelsy== Minstrelsy was America's first original contribution to the theater arts.<ref>{{cite book| last = Bean| first = Annemarie | authorlink = |author2=James Vernon Hatch |author3=Brooks McNamara | title = Inside the minstrel mask: readings in nineteenth-century blackface minstrelsy | publisher = Wesleyan University Press | year = 1996 | location = Hanover, New Hampshire | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8195-5294-1}}</ref> It was popular from just before the [[American Civil War]] to the end of the 19th Century. Today, minstrelsy and its attendant [[blackface]] is viewed as racist and anachronistic; however, it was the preeminent entertainment in the United States during the life of George H. Coes, and he was one of the most well-known and successful performers.<ref name="McCormack">{{cite news| last = McCormack| first = Mike| title = Luke Schoolcraft's life touches on minstrel shows, composing| work = Terre Haute Tribune-Star| pages = | publisher = | date = February 2, 2003| url = http://specials.tribstar.com/columns/Historical/2003/February2.html| accessdate = August 30, 2008}}</ref>
===Early career=== Coes went to California in 1852 and was associated with a number of minstrel acts, principally in [[San Francisco]] before returning East and opening with Woods and [[Christy's Minstrels]] in New York City in 1857. In 1858, Coes returned to California and joined with Sam Wells to form Coes and Wells' Minstrels.<ref>{{cite book| last = Rice| first = Edward Leroy | authorlink = | title = Monarchs of Minstrelsy from "Daddy" Rice to Date| publisher = Kenney Publishing Company | year = 1911 | location = New York, New York | pages = 366| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nvY5AAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage&dq=%22George+H.+Coes%22&source=gbs_summary_r&cad=0#PPP8,M1 | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> That partnership did not last and Coes returned to performing in other companies. In 1867, after years of performing in the minstrel companies of others, Coes joined with [[S.S. Purdy]] and [[Frank Converse (minstrel)|Frank Converse]] to form Coes, Purdy and Converse's Party which opened in [[Harlem]] on March 19, 1867.
===Partnership with Schoolcraft=== Coes joined with his old friend [[Luke Schoolcraft]] in 1874 and they formed "one of the most famous minstrel tandems in history." <ref name="McCormack"/> Schoolcraft & Coes appeared with a number of leading companies including [[Emerson's Megatherian Minstrels]] and [[Barlow, Wilson, Primrose & West]]. By 1880, the two settled with their families in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] and continued to tour throughout the country performing their minstrel act in a variety of shows and venues.
When Coes was unable to continue his career due to poor health in 1889, the partnership dissolved. Coes was stricken with paralysis in 1891 and died at his home at 205 Hampshire Street in Cambridge, Massachusetts on March 16, 1897.
==Compositions== George H. Coes produced a book of music in 1877, entitled [[George Coes' Album of Music]] which included a number of hits, including:
*Clouds and sunshine; or, I've just arrived from Dixie (1877)
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==See also== *[[Minstrel show]]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox building | name = Gerard Behar Center | native_name = מרכז ז'ראר בכר | native_name_lang = Hebrew | image = Gerard Behar Center1.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | map_dot_label = | relief = | former_names = Beit Ha'Am | status = Complete | building_type = [[Arts centre]] | architectural_style = | address = 11 Bezalel Street | location_city = [[Jerusalem]] | location_country = [[Israel]] | coordinates = | altitude = | groundbreaking_date = 1950 | start_date = | completion_date = 1961 | opened_date = 1961 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = 1983 | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | landlord = | size = | floor_count = | floor_area = | architect = A. Hoffman, [[David Resnick|David Reznik]] | architecture_firm = | known_for = | ren_architect = David Reznik | seating_type = | seating_capacity = 650-seat and 200-seat theatres | rooms = <!-- or |unit_count = --> | parking = | url = {{URL|gerard-behar.jerusalem.muni.il}} }}
'''Gerard Behar Center''' ({{lang-he|מרכז ז'ראר בכר}}) is a major [[arts centre]] in [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]], for independent theatre, dance, and musical productions, children's shows, art exhibitions, artist workshops, and festivals. In 2010 the center hosted over 900 events with attendance in excess of 263,600 participants. The center includes two theatres and is home to two dance companies, Kolben and [[Vertigo (dance company)|Vertigo]].
Formerly known as '''Beit Ha'Am''', in 1961 the newly opened site was the venue for the trial of [[Nazism|Nazi]] officer [[Adolf Eichmann]], who sat in a specially-made bulletproof glass booth during the proceedings. After the trial, the building reverted to its use as a cultural center, but in 1983 the complex was upgraded to an arts centre by the [[Jerusalem Foundation]] with funding from Eliezer and Lucie Behar of France, who renamed the center in memory of their son, Gerard, a victim of the Nazis during World War II. In 1987 the Gerard Behar Center was incorporated into the newly named Jacob & Hilda Blaustein Civic Center, which encompasses the two theatres, a dance studio, a municipal library, an [[adult education]] program, and an [[ulpan]].
==History== Beit Ha'Am ({{lang-he|בית העם}}, literally, "People's House"{{sfn|Patai|2000|p=4}}) was a public cultural program operating in various cities in Israel; it was underway in Jerusalem by 1904.<ref name=nach/> It provided public lectures, cultural evenings, a reading library, and a venue in which people could meet and discuss the issues of the day.<ref name=nach>{{cite web |url=http://www.nahlaot.co.il/%D7%9E%D7%A8%D7%9B%D7%96-%D7%96-%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A8-%D7%91%D7%9B%D7%A8.html|title= מרכז ז'ראר בכר|trans-title=Gerard Behar Center|language=Hebrew|first=Rafi|last=Kefir|publisher=Ahavat Yerushalayim|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> Lacking a permanent home, the program moved from place to place in the vicinity of [[Street of the Prophets]], with one of its better-known locations being on Isaiah Street, to the rear of the Histadrut building on [[Straus Street]].<ref name=nach/> In the 1930s and 1940s, Beit Ha'Am convened in various downtown theatres, including the [[Zion Square|Zion Cinema]], the Eden Theater, the Orion Theater, and the Edison Theater,{{sfn|Patai|2000|p=4}}<ref name=nach/> the latter of which had seating for over 2,000.{{sfn|Patai|2000|p=213}} After the establishment of the State of Israel, Beit Ha'Am occupied the Perlstein building at 70 [[Jaffa Road]].<ref name=nach/>
Jewish historian and ethnographer [[Raphael Patai]] was a frequent speaker for the popular lecture series; in his book, ''Journeyman in Jerusalem: Memories and Letters, 1933–1947'', he recalls his well-attended lecture at a commemorative evening for [[Theodor Herzl]] in 1937, a lecture on [[Josephus]] which was not received as well, and a lecture on "Jewish sea battles".{{sfn|Patai|2000|pp=213–216}} In 1944 Patai introduced a Jewish folklore studies component to Beit Ha'Am and was the scientific director for that segment.{{sfn|Patai|2000|p=436}}
In 1950 the cornerstone was laid for a permanent building for Beit Ha'Am on Bezalel Street in the [[Nachlaot]] neighborhood.<ref name=nach/> The land had been purchased by the [[Jewish National Fund]] for this purpose, and architect A. Hoffman designed the building.<ref name=nach/> While construction commenced before the declaration of the state of Israel, the project was abandoned with the onset of the [[1948 Arab–Israeli war]].<ref name=behar/> In 1955 the project was taken over by the [[Jerusalem Municipality]], which hired architect [[David Resnick|David Reznik]] to complete the plans.<ref name=nach/> The building was finally completed in 1961.<ref name=jeru>{{cite web |url=http://jerusalem.com/articles/culture_and_politics/the_gerardbehar_center_in_jerusalem-a2085|title=The Gerard-Behar Center in Jerusalem|publisher=Jerusalem.com|date=3 May 2013|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref>
==Trial of Adolf Eichmann== [[File:Adolf Eichmann at Trial1961.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Adolf Eichmann]] sits in a bulletproof glass booth at his trial]] With the capture of the Nazi officer Adolf Eichmann in [[Buenos Aires]] and the decision by the Israeli government to try him for [[crimes against humanity]], the newly opened Beit Ha'Am was chosen as the site for the trial, in part due to its ability to accommodate the many journalists and media correspondents expected to attend.{{sfn|Shandler|1999|p=90}} The building was enclosed by a {{convert|10|ft|adj=on}} high security fence and a holding cell for Eichmann was established on-site for the duration of the trial.{{sfn|Shandler|1999|p=90}}<ref name=behar>{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-165084941.html |title=How Behar Changed Its Stars|first=Abe|last=Selig|date=11 June 2009|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam}}</ref>
The four-month trial, which began on April 11, 1961,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov.il/archivegov_eng/publications/electronicpirsum/eichmantrial/eichmantrialintroduction.htm |title=The Eichmann Trial: Fifty years after |accessdate=1 April 2016 |publisher=[[Israel State Archives]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407091325/http://www.archives.gov.il/archivegov_eng/publications/electronicpirsum/eichmantrial/eichmantrialintroduction.htm |archivedate=7 April 2016 |df= }}</ref> was highly publicized and covered by radio, newspaper, and television journalists from around the world. Of the 756 seats made available in the theatre, 474 were designated for members of the press; journalists also viewed the proceedings via closed-circuit television in an adjacent press room. Another 570 viewers watched on a closed-circuit screen in the nearby Ratisbonne Monastery.{{sfn|Shandler|1999|pp=90–91}} Videotape was flown daily to the United States for broadcast the following day. A [[bulletproof glass]] wall was erected between the stage where the judges sat and the spectator seating, and Eichmann sat inside his own bulletproof glass booth with armed guards at his side.{{sfn|Shandler|1999|p=90}} The trial concluded on August 14, 1961; on December 13 the court found Eichmann guilty of crimes against humanity. The death penalty was issued on December 15.<ref name=yad>{{cite web |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/exhibitions/eichmann/verdict.asp|title=Eichmann's Trial in Jerusalem: Verdict|publisher=[[Yad Vashem]]|year=2016|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> Eichmann's attorneys appealed to the Israeli Supreme Court, but the court upheld the verdict on May 29, 1962.<ref name=yad/> After a last-minute appeal for [[clemency]] to Israeli president [[Yitzhak Ben-Zvi]] was also refused, Eichmann was executed shortly after midnight on June 1, 1962.<ref name=yad/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/exhibitions/eichmann/execution_verdict.asp|title=Eichmann's Trial in Jerusalem: Execution of the Verdict|publisher=Yad Vashem|year=2016|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref>
==Renovation== [[File:Gerard Behar Center2.jpg|left|thumb|Gerard Behar Center entrance]] Following the Eichmann trial, Beit Ha'Am reverted to its function as a cultural center. In the early 1980s<ref name=jeru/> the Jerusalem Foundation undertook the creation of a major [[arts centre]] on the site and found a donor in Eliezer and Lucie Behar of France. The renovation, designed by David Reznik<ref name=nach/> and completed in 1983, upgraded the theatre in which the Eichmann trial had taken place into a 650-seat performance venue for theatre, music, and dance, and added a second, 200-seat theatre to the complex.<ref name=behar/> Both theatres are handicapped accessible.<ref name=jeru/> The theatre complex was renamed the Gerard Behar Center in memory of the donors' son, who had been murdered by the Nazis.<ref name=behar/><ref name=jeru/> A circular plaza fronting the entrance was also created in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.jerusalemfoundation.org/culture/theater/an-pritzker-plaza.aspx |title=A. N. Pritzker Plaza – 1983 |publisher=[[Jerusalem Foundation]] |accessdate=1 April 2016 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Events== [[File:Kolben Dance Studio.jpg|right|thumb|Kolben Dance Studio]] The Gerard Behar Center hosts theatre, music, and dance performances; folk dancing; ethnic shows; Russian-, French-, and Arabic-language shows; plays; comedy shows; and children's performances.<ref name=behar/><ref name=found10/> From time to time it works with other bodies to stage independent productions, such as a "Hot Jazz Series" which brings together the "best musicians" from Israel and abroad to perform "jazz, salsa, classical, Latin, African and Jewish music".<ref name=jeru/> The all-female [[Theatre Company Jerusalem]] has staged the world premiere of several works at the Center, including the 1992 Israeli-Palestinian play ''The Jasmine Bush''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-5994562.html|title= Israeli, Palestinian playwrights don't beat around the 'Bush'|first=Helen|last=Kaye|date=4 September 1995|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=The Jerusalem Post|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam}}</ref> and the 2000 play ''Sota''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-37853503.html|title='Sota' uncovered at the Behar Center|first=Barry|last=Davis|date=15 November 2000|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=The Jerusalem Post|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam}}</ref> The Center is the home of two dance companies, Vertigo and Kolben.<ref name=jeru/><ref name=muni>{{cite web|url=https://www.jerusalem.muni.il/en/Culture/Theaters/Pages/GerardBeharCenter.aspx|title=The Gerard Behar Center|publisher=Jerusalem Municipality|accessdate=1 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414054011/https://www.jerusalem.muni.il/en/Culture/Theaters/Pages/GerardBeharCenter.aspx#|archive-date=2016-04-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The Center is the site for events held in conjunction with the [[Israel Festival]], the Jerusalem Arts Festival,<ref name=jeru/><ref name=muni/> and [[Yom HaShoah|Holocaust Remembrance Day]]. On the latter holiday, a free "Singing and Remembering" event combines performances by singers and songwriters with audience participation, as attendees are encouraged to "share stories about their personal connection to the Holocaust".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itraveljerusalem.com/events/holocaust-memorial-day-in-jerusalem/|title=Holocaust Remembrance Day in Jerusalem 2016|publisher=I Travel Jerusalem|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4513510,00.html|title=Holocaust Memorial Day 2014: From Extermination to Liberation|publisher=[[Ynetnews]]|date=27 April 2014|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Travel/Around-Israel/Commemorating-Holocaust-Remembrance-Day-in-Jlem|title=Commemorating Holocaust Remembrance Day in J'lem|first=Loren|last=Minsky|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=17 April 2012|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> The Center is also the venue for the annual Rabbi [[Shlomo Carlebach (musician)|Shlomo Carlebach]] Memorial Concert, the Machol Shalem (Whole Dance) Festival, and the Hullegeb Israeli Ethiopian Arts Festival.<ref name=found/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.confederationhouse.org/en/festivals/2014-04-28-11-56-10|title=The Fourth Hullegeb Israeli Ethiopian Arts Festival|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=1 April 2016|publisher=Kalman Sultanik Confederation House|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331235705/http://www.confederationhouse.org/en/festivals/2014-04-28-11-56-10|archivedate=31 March 2016|df=}}</ref>
Tens of thousands<ref name=blau/> of [[K–12]] students visit the Gerard Behar Center each school year as part of the government's "Cultural Basket" program ({{lang-he|אומנות לעם}}, ''Omanut La'Am''), which mandates student attendance at "performances, art films and/or art exhibitions five or six times a year as part of their curriculum"; these activities are subsidized and transportation is provided.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.org.il/directory/culturalpolicy.asp |title=Cultural Policy and Infrastructure |publisher=Israel Arts Directory |accessdate=1 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401230424/http://culture.org.il/directory/culturalpolicy.asp |archivedate=1 April 2016 |df= }}</ref> The [[Israel Broadcasting Authority]] sponsors an annual Competition for Young Artists in which musicians aged 18 to 30 compete for scholarships and the Gerard Behar Grand Prize.<ref name=found>{{cite web|url=http://projects.jerusalemfoundation.org/culture/theater/gerard-behar-center.aspx |title=Gerard Behar Center – 1983 |publisher=Jerusalem Foundation |accessdate=1 April 2016 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Center hosts workshops by artists from the United States and England, and exhibitions of art and photography primarily by local artists.<ref name=behar/> Lectures, seminars, conferences, and gatherings of organizations, institutions, and government offices round out the annual calendar of events.<ref name=found10/><ref name=muni/>
According to the 2006 Jerusalem Foundation report, both theatres in the Gerard Behar Center "are nearly always filled to capacity for events".<ref name=blau>{{cite web|url=http://jerusalemfoundation.co4.codeoasis.com/uploads/%5CCommunity%5CBuilding%20Community%5Ccommunity%20centres%5Cblaustein%20report%202006.pdf |title=The Jacob and Hilda Blaustein Civic Center |year=2006 |publisher=Jerusalem Foundation |accessdate=1 April 2016 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In calendar year 2010, there were approximately 63,300 attendees at theatrical performances, 31,800 attendees at dance and musical performances, and 36,100 children attending "Cultural Basket" events.<ref name=found10/> The Center hosted over 900 events in 2010, with attendance in excess of 263,600 participants.<ref name=found10/>
Notwithstanding its prominence, the Center has a permanent staff of only four: a director-general, a secretary, a technician, and a ticket sales manager. Outside staff is brought in to produce large events.<ref name=behar/>
==Other activities== The seven-story building adjoining the Gerard Behar Center contains an adult and youth reading library,<ref name=jeru/> an [[adult education]] program known as the Popular University,<ref name=found10>{{cite web|url=http://jerusalemfoundation.co4.codeoasis.com/uploads/%5CReport%20-%20Blaustein%20Civic%20Center%202010-11.pdf |title=The Jacob & Hilda Blaustein Civic Center Report 2010/11 |year=2011 |publisher=The Jerusalem Foundation |accessdate=1 April 2016 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and Ulpan Beit Ha'Am, the largest and oldest Hebrew-language [[ulpan]] (language immersion course) in Jerusalem.<ref name=ulpan>{{cite web|url=https://www1.jerusalem.muni.il/jer_sys/publish/showPublishEng.asp?pub_id=44849 |title=Ulpan Beit Ha'Am |publisher=Jerusalem Municipality |accessdate=1 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151212083704/https://www1.jerusalem.muni.il/jer_sys/publish/showPublishEng.asp?pub_id=44849 |archivedate=12 December 2015 |df= }}</ref> The ulpan, operated by the Jerusalem Municipality,<ref>{{cite book|ref=harv|url= https://books.google.co.il/books?id=kpi9CQAAQBAJ&pg=PT189 |title= Lonely Planet Israel & the Palestinian Territories|page=189|publisher=[[Lonely Planet]]|year=2015|isbn=1743605471 }}</ref> offers courses for new immigrants, tourists, and retirees,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbn.org.il/aliyahpedia/education-ulpan/ulpan-directory/beit-haam/|title=Beit Ha'Am Ulpan|publisher=[[Nefesh B'Nefesh]]|date=September 2015|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> and conducts field trips to acquaint new immigrants with Israel.<ref name=ulpan/> A dance/exercise studio is on the ground floor of the building. In 1987 the Jerusalem Foundation incorporated the Gerard Behar theatre complex, the Beit Ha'Am educational and library facilities, and the dance studio into a larger public complex known as the Jacob & Hilda Blaustein Civic Center.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.jerusalemfoundation.org/culture/theater/jacob-and-hilda-blaustein-civic-center.aspx |title=Jacob & Hilden Blaustein Civic Center – 1987 |publisher=Jerusalem Foundation |accessdate=1 April 2016 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Mural== [[File:Gabriel Cohen mural at Gerard Behar Center.jpg|right|thumb|Mural on the Gerard Behar Center]] The northern façade of the Gerard Behar Center, facing Bezalel Street, features a {{convert|160|sqm|adj=on}} [[mural]] titled "Around the World in 92 Days".{{sfn|Ackerman|2007|p=192}}<ref name=ziva/> The [[triptych]] painting is a large-scale reproduction of a 1976 painting by Jerusalem artist Gabriel Cohen; the original is housed in the [[Israel Museum]].{{sfn|Ackerman|2007|p=192}}<ref name=ziva>{{cite web |url= http://www.jerusalemite.net/blog/3175/jerusalem-stone-gets-colorful|title=Jerusalem Stone Gets Colorful|first=Ziva|last=Haller Rubenstein|date=10 September 2008|accessdate=1 April 2016|publisher=Jerusalemite.net}}</ref> Painted in [[naïve art]] style, the painting depicts world landmarks such as the [[Eiffel Tower]] and [[Arc de Triomphe]] in Paris, the [[Walls of Jerusalem]] and the [[Dome of the Rock]] in Jerusalem, the pyramids of Egypt, the [[Leaning Tower of Pisa]], bridges in [[London]], and sights in [[India]], with people and animals of all kinds walking along the streets and bridges below.<ref name=jeru/><ref name=ziva/> The mural was produced by Cité de la Creation, which painted five ''[[trompe-l'œil]]'' murals in downtown Jerusalem.{{sfn|Ackerman|2007|p=192}}<ref name=ziva/> On the sidewalk across the street from the mural stand five small pillars topped with engraved metal plates describing the work in Hebrew and English, and depicting reproductions of different parts of the painting for visually-handicapped persons, with explanations in [[Braille]].
==References==
===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}}
===Sources=== *{{cite book|ref=harv|url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=geIuAQAAIAAJ&q=gerard+behar|title=The Mysteries of Jerusalem: 101 unique sites in the Holy City|first=Adam|last=Ackerman|year=2007|publisher=Rubin Mass|isbn= 9650902112}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|url= https://books.google.co.il/books?id=IrF7ZYWMO8MC&pg=PA436 |title= Journeyman in Jerusalem: Memories and Letters, 1933–1947|first=Raphael|last=Patai|authorlink=Raphael Patai|year=2000|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn= 0739102095}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=NobvLCXFIOcC&pg=PA90 |title=While America Watches: Televising the Holocaust|first=Jeffrey|last=Shandler|year=1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0195182588}}
==External links== *{{Commons category-inline}}
