{{Infobox person | name = Rodolphe Salis | image = Salis Rodolphe.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1851|5|29}} | birth_place = [[Châtellerault]], [[Vienne]], [[France]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|1897|3|20|1851|5|29}} | death_place = [[Naintré]], [[Vienne]], [[France]] | nationality = French | known_for = [[Le Chat Noir]] | occupation = }}
'''Louis Rodolphe Salis'''<ref>Named ''Constant Maximin Rodolphe Salis'' on his birth certificate dated {{date|30 May 1851 }}.</ref> ({{date|29 May 1851}} – {{date|20 March 1897}}) was the creator, host and owner of the [[Le Chat Noir]] ("The Black Cat") [[cabaret]] (known briefly in 1881 at its beginning as "Cabaret Artistique.") With this establishment Salis is remembered as the creator of the modern cabaret: a nightclub where the patrons could sit at tables with alcoholic drinks and enjoy variety acts on a stage, introduced by a master of ceremonies who interacted with the audience.
==Biography== [[File:CHAT NOIR journal, number 152, 6 Decembre 1884.jpg|thumbnail|''CHAT NOIR'' journal, number 152, 6 Decembre 1884.]]
The son of a distiller in [[Châtellerault]], Salis came to Paris in 1872, after leaving the regiment in which he had undertaken military service. He moved into the [[Hotel de Rome]] on [[Rue de Seine]], in the [[Latin Quarter]].
He founded "L'école vibrante" (The Vibrant School), soon renamed the "L'école iriso-subversive de Chicago" (The Chicago Iriso-Subversive School)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tpc86.info/depuis1964.php|title=SPECTACLES DU TPC DEPUIS 1964|work=tpc86.info}}</ref> in order to draw attention to his artistic group. In fact he was earning a living by making [[stations of the cross]] and other religious objects, that he and his friends painted.
"In fact, it [The School] had the overall intended, but not admitted, immediate aim of making a series of Stations of the Cross to sell at eight and fourteen francs each, in a shop selling religious articles in the Saint Sulpice. The very tedious work was divided between the four "students" according to their different natures. Rene Gilbert painted heads; Wagner hands; Antonio de La Gandara draperies; Salis, finally, backgrounds and landscapes ..."<ref>''The Song in Montmartre'', Michael Herbert, ed. The Round Table</ref>
In order to combine art and alcoholic beverage, Salis had the idea of creating a café in "the purest style of Louis XII ... with a chandelier of wrought iron from the Byzantine period, and where the gentry, the burghers and peasants are now invited to drink absinthe after the usual manner of Victor Hugo and Garibaldi, and [[hypocras]] in golden bowls.<ref>''Absinthe. A Franco-Swiss fairy: fairy Franco-Swiss'', Noel Benedict, ed. Cabédita, 2001</ref> In reality, the first tavern called The Black Cat ([[Le Chat Noir]]), opened in November 1881 in a two-room building at 84 Boulevard Rochechouart (a site now commemorated by a plaque), began by serving bad wine and with a rather inferior decor. But from the first, at the door, guests were greeted by a [[Swiss guard]], splendidly bedecked and covered with gold from head to foot, supposedly responsible for bringing in the painters and poets who arrived, while barring the "infamous priests and the military." Salis' tongue-in-cheek admirational piece was on a high marble fireplace: ''The skull of [[Louis XIII]] as a child''.<ref>''Paris, crossroads of arts and letters, 1880-1918'', Jacqueline Baldran, ed. L'Harmattan, 2002</ref>
The first site's success was assured with the wholesale arrival of a group of radical young writers and artists called ''Les Hydropathes'' (“those who are afraid of water”), led by the journalist [[Emile Goudeau]]. The group claimed to be averse to water, preferring wine and beer. Goudeau’s club first met in his house on the [[Rive Gauche (Paris)|Rive Gauche]] (left bank), but had become so popular that it outgrew its meeting place. Salis, on meeting Goudeau, convinced him to transfer the club across the river [[Seine]] to 84 Boulevard Rochechouart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonjourparis.com/story/chat-noir-montmartre-cabaret/|title=Le Chat Noir: Historic Montmartre Cabaret|author=Anna Meakin|work=Bonjour Paris}}</ref>
[[File:Théophile-Alexandre Steinlen - Tournée du Chat Noir de Rodolphe Salis (Tour of Rodolphe Salis' Chat Noir) - Google Art Project.jpg|left|thumb|Now iconic [[Theophile-Alexandre Steinlen|Steinlen]] poster advertising the approaching tour of The Black Cat show, 1896.]] Le Chat Noir also soon outgrew its first site. On 10 June 1885, with great fanfare, Salis moved to new premises located 12 Rue Victor-Masse (which before 1885 had been Rue de Laval 12). Very quickly, poets and singers who performed at The Black Cat found the best practice for their craft to be had in Paris. Le Chat Noir eventually closed down in 1896. (After the death of Salis, a third Le Chat Noir was opened at 68, Boulevard de Clichy in 1907.)
Salis acted as impresario and (along with cabaret singer [[Aristide Bruant]]) as emcee, MC, or ''conférencier''. The greetings from Salis rang out often at the expense of customers. Those who left early were insulted, and those who arrived late were banished to a corner. Salis would arrest a customer with a "Well, you're finally out of prison?" or comment "What have you done with your chick from yesterday?" to a new client obviously accompanied by his wife. One evening, the future King [[Edward VII of England|Edward VII]] was addressed by Salis: "Well, look here: it looks like the [[Prince of Wales]] all [[drunkenness|pissed]]!"
Every Friday, luncheon was an opportunity to prepare for performances and the editing of a humorous magazine. With legendary stinginess,<ref>Journal ''The Châtelleraudais'' December 20O7</ref> Salis found every excuse for not paying his staff, suppliers and artists. With some success he even asked to be paid by those whom he hosted at The Black Cat. But his patter to the guests and his organizational skills and personality attracted exceptional artists of all kinds, and a large crowd. The combination of a bar with entertainment (now the standard [[cabaret]] theme), was novel. In addition, Salis had the idea of playing music in his tavern by installing a piano,<ref>"Hommage à Salis le Grand", in ''88 notes pour piano solo'', [[Jean-Pierre Thiollet]], Neva Editions, 2015, p. 146. {{ISBN|978 2 3505 5192 0}}</ref> at that time an innovation which was soon banned for newer establishments, and which thereafter allowed him to gain an advantage over the competition.
"Male, square-shouldered, red hair dyed vermilion," Salis was described by [[Lawrence Tailhade]], "ageless, though stout, his face channelled by many wrinkles, his chest in a romantic doublet whose floral satin contrasted with the sobriety of a dark coat. Intact, his tawny hair was consistent with his coppery beard and gave him the air of a Flemish trooper ... [He had] a bronze baritone, emphatic, biting and sarcastic, whose thunders cynically put down the Philistines ... [He had] a prodigiously charlatan nature."<ref>Lawrence Tailhade disliked because of Salis; Salis mockery made Public, ''Lawrence Tailhade or provocation considered a lifestyle'', Gilles Picq, Jean - Pierre Rioux, ed. Maisonneuve & Larose, 2001</ref>
In the 1890s, Salis took his The Black Cat entertainment company touring through France, hiring theatres and venues, a practice that was not current at that time. He often refused, under various pretexts, to pay the venue hire charge.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}}
He died in [[Naintré]] in 1897. {{Clear}} ==Tributes== * In the department of [[Vienne]] to: [[Châtellerault]] [[Naintré]] [[Marigny-Brizay]] a street bears his name. * 18 Boulevard de Clichy in Paris stands a plaque: "Here was the tomb of the Black Cat founded by Rodolphe Salis ..."<ref>''On the walls of Paris: Guide plaques'' Dautriat Alain, ed. Inventory, 1999</ref>
==References== <references/>
==Sources== * Mariel Oberthür, Musée d'Orsay,''The Black Cat, 1881-1897: exhibition at the Musée d'Orsay from February 25 to May 31, 1992'', Meeting of National Museums, 1992 * Lawrence Tailhade, ''Little Memoirs of the Life'', ed. BiblioBazaar, 2008 * Anne de Bercy, Armand Ziwès, ''Montmartre ... In the evening'', ed. Grasset, 1951 * Edmond Deschaumes, ''Le Cabaret du Chat Noir,'' Journal encyclopedic 1897
==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Rodolphe Salis}} * [http://www.chanson.udenap.org/fiches_bio/salis_rodolphe.htm Biography of Rodolphe Salis]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Salis, Rodolphe}} [[Category:1851 births]] [[Category:People from Châtellerault]] [[Category:1897 deaths]] [[Category:Cabaret]] [[Category:French theatre directors]] [[Category:People of Montmartre]]

revision.comment: /* 1963–1966: Enka's independence and collapse */ also, it doesn't mean literally "woman in hakodate". it means "woman of hakodate" or "hakodate woman"
revision.text:
{{Infobox music genre | name = Ryūkōka | bgcolor = #87CEEB | color = black | stylistic_origins = {{hlist|[[Traditional pop]]|[[Classical music|Western classical music]]|[[operetta]]|[[vocal music]]|[[Dodoitsu]]|[[min'yō]]|[[jazz]]|[[blues]]|[[tango]]}} | cultural_origins = 1920s, Japan | instruments = {{hlist|[[Vocals]]|[[classical guitar]]|[[mandolin]]|[[violin]]|[[accordion]]}} | derivatives = {{hlist|[[Enka]]|[[kayōkyoku]]|[[J-pop]]|[[trot (music)|trot]]}} | subgenrelist = | subgenres = | fusiongenres = | regional_scenes = | other_topics = }} {{nihongo|'''Ryūkōka'''|[[wikt:流行|流行]][[wikt:歌|歌]]||literally "Popular Song"}} is a Japanese [[music genre|musical genre]].<ref>貴志俊彦『東アジア流行歌アワー――越境する音 交錯する音楽人(The East Asia Pop Song Hour: Border-Crossing Sounds, Entangled Musicians)』岩波書店, 2013, {{ISBN|4000291157}}</ref> The term originally denoted any kind of "[[popular music]]" in Japanese. Therefore, ''imayō'', which was promoted by [[Emperor Go-Shirakawa]] in the [[Heian period]], was a kind of ''ryūkōka''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.city.kyoto.jp/somu/rekishi/fm/nenpyou/htmlsheet/bunka05.html|title=Imayō|publisher=[[Kyoto]]|accessdate=2009-03-06|language=ja}}</ref> Today, however, ''ryūkōka'' refers specifically to Japanese popular music from the late 1920s through the early 1960s.<ref>Ewbank, Alison J. and Papageorgiou, Fouli T. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mHjPFLLWRgQC&pg=PA160 Whose Master's Voice?: The Development of Popular Music in Thirteen Cultures]''. ''[[Google Books]]''. via Greenwood Publishing Group. 1997. 160. {{ISBN|978-0-313-27772-6}}</ref> Some of the roots of ''ryūkōka'' were developed from Western [[classical music]].<ref name="miyagawa">{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0604/0604112215/1.php|script-title=ja:ジャズの香り―無国籍歌謡の人生・宮川泰|publisher=[[JANJAN]]|date=2006-04-13|accessdate=2009-02-19|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110184332/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0604/0604112215/1.php|archivedate=2007-11-10|df=}}</ref> ''Ryūkōka'' ultimately split into two genres: ''[[enka]]'' and ''poppusu''.<ref>Roberson, James E. and Suzuki, Nobue. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=gF6nxvmGabAC&pg=PA78 Men and Masculinities in Contemporary Japan]''. ''[[Google Books]]''. via Routledge. 2003. 78. {{ISBN|978-0-415-24446-6}}</ref> Unlike ''enka'', archetypal ''ryūkōka'' songs did not use the ''kobushi'' method of singing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sakuhokusha.co.jp/arch/2003/100ryuko.htm|script-title=ja:小沢昭一的流行歌・昭和のこころ|publisher=Sakuhosha|accessdate=2009-02-28|language=ja}}</ref> ''Ryūkōka'' used [[legato]]. [[Bin Uehara]] and [[Yoshio Tabata]] are considered to be among the founders of the modern style of ''kobushi'' singing.<ref name="elekitel4">{{cite web|url=http://elekitel.jp/elekitel/special/2006/13/sp_02_d.htm |title=Special 2. Japanese popular music (4) |publisher=[[Toshiba]] |date=November 2006 |accessdate=2009-04-10 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080619165647/http://elekitel.jp/elekitel/special/2006/13/sp_02_d.htm |archivedate=2008-06-19 |df= }}</ref>
Many composers and singers of ''ryūkōka'' went on to earn official distinctions; [[Ichiro Fujiyama]] and composers [[Masao Koga]] and [[Ryoichi Hattori]] received the [[People's Honour Award]] in later years.
Although ''enka'' branched off from ''ryūkōka'', many singers of the latter genre proclaimed strong disdain for its stylistic descendant. In a 1981 interview, [[Noriko Awaya]] said "Whenever I hear ''enka'', I have to get away from the music because I feel like vomiting."<ref name="nikkansports">{{cite web|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/jinji/1999/seikyo990926.html|title=Tragic News: Noriko Awaya|publisher=[[Nikkan Sports]]|year=1999|accessdate=2009-01-17|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090222221654/http://www.nikkansports.com/jinji/1999/seikyo990926.html|archivedate=2009-02-22|df=}}</ref><ref group=fn>Original text: "演歌を聴くと胸がムカムカするから、あれが聴こえてくると逃げ回るんです。"</ref>
==History== {{multiple image | footer = Singer [[Sumako Matsui]] and composer [[Shinpei Nakayama]] | width = 140 | image1 = Sumako Matsui cropped.jpg | image2 = 中山晋平.jpg }}
=== 1914–1927: Origin === {{see also|Min'yō}} In 1914, [[Sumako Matsui]]'s song "[[Katyusha's song]]", composed by [[Shinpei Nakayama]], was used as a theme of the rendition ''[[Resurrection (novel)|Resurrection]]'' in Japan. The record of the song sold 20,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fma.co.jp/pc/program/morning/today/0326/index.html|title=March 26|publisher=FM Aichi|accessdate=2009-02-19|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304195953/http://www.fma.co.jp/pc/program/morning/today/0326/index.html|archivedate=2016-03-04|df=}}</ref> One theory holds that this was the first ''ryūkōka'' song, which was made by [[Hogetsu Shimamura]]'s order: "the tune between Japanese popular folk music and Western music".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.city.itoigawa.niigata.jp/sisetu/rekimin/sakusi02.htm |title=Lyricist Sōma Gyofū's notable songs |publisher=[[Itoigawa, Niigata]] |accessdate=2009-02-18 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416041324/http://www.city.itoigawa.niigata.jp/sisetu/rekimin/sakusi02.htm |archivedate=April 16, 2009 }}</ref><ref group=fn>Original text: "日本の俗謡と西洋歌曲の中間のような旋律"</ref> However, street performers called {{nihongo|"[[enka]]-shi"|演歌師}} had been popular until record labels such as the [[JVC|Victor Company of Japan]] began to produce songs in the early [[Shōwa period]].<ref name="habunominato">{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0603/0603220226/1.php |script-title=ja:昭和流行歌の幕開け《波浮の港》 |author=Kiyomaro Kikuchi |publisher=[[JANJAN]] |date=2006-03-23 |accessdate=2009-01-23 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110184316/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0603/0603220226/1.php |archivedate=2007-11-10 |df= }}</ref>
Although Matsui committed suicide after Shimamura's death, Nakayama continued to develop his music. During his career, he composed about 3,000 songs such as the 1921 song "[[Teru teru bozu]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.city.nakano.nagano.jp/city/shogai/shinpei/sinnpeigyouseki.htm |title=Shinpei Nakayama's Profile |publisher=[[Nakano, Nagano|Nakano City]] |accessdate=2009-05-15 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111080700/http://www.city.nakano.nagano.jp/city/shogai/shinpei/sinnpeigyouseki.htm |archivedate=November 11, 2007 }}</ref> Nakayama transferred Japanese traditional music to [[staff (music)|staff]]-style by main force. His 1921 song {{nihongo|"Sendō Kouta"|船頭小唄}} was later covered by various singers, but was at first best known for being covered by [[violin]] enka-shi {{nihongo|Shunyo Tottori|鳥取春陽|Tottori Shun'yō|1900–1932}} featuring [[Orchestra]]. The [[pentatonic scale]] used in this song was "[[Minor scale]] without forth and seventh [[degree (music)|degree]]". However, the music based on the scale had difficult in presenting [[chord (music)|chord]] and [[harmony]] because [[traditional Japanese music]] didn't adopt [[equal temperament]].<ref name="soshienka">{{cite web|url=http://elekitel.jp/elekitel/special/2006/13/sp_02_a.htm|title=Special 2. Japanese popular music (1)|publisher=[[Toshiba]]|date=October 2006|accessdate=2009-02-22|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419051011/http://elekitel.jp/elekitel/special/2006/13/sp_02_a.htm|archivedate=2015-04-19|df=}}</ref>
Nakayama's songs were based on Japanese folk music called ''[[min'yō]]'', but also adopted Western musical style. Therefore, his music was called {{nihongo|"Shin Min'yō"|新民謡|lit. "New Folk Song"}}.<ref name="soshienka" />
===1928–1930: Beginning of popularity=== {{double image|right|藤原義江.jpg|152|Chiyako Sato.jpg|125|[[Yoshie Fujiwara]] and [[Chiyako Sato]]}} In the early Showa period, the [[microphone]] was introduced into the popular music of Japan. [[Teiichi Futamura]] released his cover version of {{nihongo|"Sing me A Song of Araby"|アラビヤの唄|Arabiya no Uta}} in 1928. The song was originally composed by [[Fred Fisher]]. [[Chiyako Sato]]'s 1928 song {{nihongo|"Habu no Minato"|波浮の港|lit. "Port of Habu"}}{{#tag:ref|Habu is a port in [[Izu Ōshima]].<ref name="habunominato" />|group=fn}}, composed by Nakayama, sold 100,000 copies.<ref name="habunominato" /> The song was also sung by singer [[Yoshie Fujiwara]].<ref name="habunominato" /> Chiyako Sato's 1929 song "Tokyo March" sold more than 300,000 copies.<ref>Atkins, Taylor E. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xCFPL5svwhQC&pg=PA66 Blue Nippon: Authenticating Jazz in Japan]''. ''[[Google Books]]''. via Duke University Press. 2001. 66. {{ISBN|978-0-8223-2721-9}}</ref>
===1931–1937: Rising popularity=== {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | header = | width = 160 | image1 = 藤山一郎.jpg | caption1 = [[People's Honour Award]] winning singer [[Ichiro Fujiyama]] | image2 = Hideko Takamine and Taro Shoji cropped.jpg | caption2 = [[Hideko Takamine]] and [[Taro Shoji]] | image3 = Noriko Awaya.jpg | caption3 = [[Noriko Awaya]], the "Queen of Blues" in Japan }} {{see also|Dodoitsu|Ero guro|Geisha}} Some of the country's first major stars were singer [[Ichiro Fujiyama]] and composer [[Masao Koga]]. Koga attempted to initiate fusion of Western jazz and Japanese [[dodoitsu]].<ref name="janjan">{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0604/0604182584/1.php |script-title=ja:酒は涙か溜息か―藤山一郎音楽学校停学事件 |author=Kiyomaro Kikuchi |publisher=[[JANJAN]] |date=2006-04-20 |accessdate=2009-01-16 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206173933/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0604/0604182584/1.php |archivedate=2009-02-06 |df= }}</ref> Fujiyama's 1931 song {{Nihongo|"Sake wa Namida ka Tameiki ka"|酒は涙か溜息か|lit. "Is Sake Tears or Sighs?"}}, composed by Koga, became a major hit in Japan. This song created a fusion of Fujiyama's [[crooner|crooning]] and Koga's [[guitar]] play.<ref name="janjan" /> Using the vocal technic ''[[Mezza Voce]]'' with a microphone, Fujiyama sang the song by the deep voice of not [[Opera]]'s [[G minor]] but [[D minor]].<ref name="janjan" /> Fujiyama's song {{nihongo|"Oka o Koete"|丘を越えて|lit. "Beyond the Hill"}} sold 600,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yamaha.co.jp/himekuri/view.php?ymd=19990408|title=April 8: Birthdate of Ichiro Fujiyama|publisher=[[Yamaha]]|accessdate=2009-02-20|language=ja}}</ref> However, Fujiyama was an elite student, who specialized Western [[classical music]] in the [[Tokyo University of the Arts|Tokyo Music School]]. ''Ryūkōka'' songs often dealt with the "[[Ero guro|Ero Guro Nansensu]]" things.<ref name="aikawa">{{cite web|url=http://www.jade.dti.ne.jp/~onodera/radio.html|title=NHK Kokumin Kayō: Singing Radio Kayō|publisher=Yumi Aikawa Official Website|accessdate=2009-01-27|language=ja}}</ref> Since his school regarded ''ryūkōka'' as bad form at that time, Fujiyama was once suspended from the school, though Fujiyama was not dismissed from the school because [[Klaus Pringsheim, Sr.]], a professor of the school, opposed the proposal of Fujiyama's expulsion.<ref name="janjan" />
This period also saw the popularity of ''[[geisha]]'' singers such as [[Ichimaru]] and [[Katsutaro Kouta]]. Katsutaro became famous when Fujiyama was turned out of ''ryūkōka''. Her song {{nihongo|"Shima no Musume"|島の娘|lit. "Island Girl"}} sold 600,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.city.niigata.jp/info/gikai_jimu/honkaigi/seigan_tinjou/bunsyoWEB/seigan2go.htm |script-title=ja:新潟市議会請願第2号文書表 |publisher=[[Niigata, Niigata|Niigata City]] |year=2003 |accessdate=2009-02-19 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905202529/http://www.city.niigata.jp/info/gikai_jimu/honkaigi/seigan_tinjou/bunsyoWEB/seigan2go.htm |archivedate=September 5, 2012 }}</ref> Katsutaro and Issei Mishima recorded [[duet]] song "Tokyo Ondo". The song was composed by Shinpei Nakayama and was released in 1933. The single "Tokyo Ondo" sold 1,200,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.nhk.or.jp/chronicle/B10001200998104110130044/|script-title=ja:踊り踊って東京音頭 昭和８年|publisher=[[NHK]]|accessdate=2009-02-20|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811184316/http://archives.nhk.or.jp/chronicle/B10001200998104110130044/|archivedate=2011-08-11|df=}}</ref>
When Fujiyama sang Western classic [[lied]] songs, those songs were called "[[kayōkyoku]]", but the term "kayōkyoku" went on to be used as another name of ''ryūkōka'' in [[NHK]].<ref name="elekitel">{{cite web|url=http://elekitel.jp/elekitel/special/2006/13/sp_02_b.htm|title=Special 2. Japanese popular music (2)|publisher=[[Toshiba]]|date=November 2006|accessdate=2009-02-18|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201825/http://elekitel.jp/elekitel/special/2006/13/sp_02_b.htm|archivedate=2016-03-03|df=}}</ref> At first, Koga was a good co-worker for Fujiyama but they moved apart from each other because Koga sought "Japanese" music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0609/0609201453/1.php|script-title=ja:太平洋戦争直前の歌謡曲|author=Kiyomaro Kikuchi|publisher=[[JANJAN]]|date=2006-04-20|accessdate=2009-02-08|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110184514/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0609/0609201453/1.php|archivedate=2007-11-10|df=}}</ref> On the other hand, Yoshie Fujiwara drew a clear line between him and ''ryūkōka'' and established the [[Fujiwara Opera]] in 1934, launching the establishment of Japanese [[Opera]].<ref name="habunominato" /> [[Baritone]] singer [[Taro Shoji]]'s 1934 song {{nihongo|"Akagi no Komoriuta"|赤城の子守唄|lit. "Berceuse of [[Mount Akagi|Akagi]]"}} also became popular, though he did not know [[Kunisada Chūji]], the theme of the song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0606/0606146008/1.php|script-title=ja:不動の魂・東海林太郎そのデビュー|publisher=[[JANJAN]]|date=2006-06-15|accessdate=2009-05-10|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110184407/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0606/0606146008/1.php|archivedate=2007-11-10|df=}}</ref>
[[Soprano]] singer [[Noriko Awaya]] also sang ''ryūkōka'', but the [[Tokyo College of Music|Toyo Music School]] once annulled her graduation.<ref name="nikkansports" /> However, her song {{nihongo|"Wakare no Blues"|別れのブルース|lit. "Farewell Blues"}} became a hit in 1937.<ref name="nikkansports" /> The song was composed by jazz composer [[Ryoichi Hattori]].<ref name="fujitv">{{cite web|url=http://wwwz.fujitv.co.jp/events/art-net/clsc_01concert/330.html |script-title=ja:服部良一生誕100周年記念コンサート |publisher=Fuji Television |year=2006 |accessdate=2009-01-24 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103215238/http://wwwz.fujitv.co.jp/events/art-net/clsc_01concert/330.html |archivedate=November 3, 2007 }}</ref> She was called "Queen of Blues", though term "[[blues]]" was just a song title.<ref name="nikkansports" />
===1937–1945: Influences of war=== [[File:愛国行進曲（歌詞）.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The lyric sheet of "Patriotic March"]] {{see also|Gunka|Rōkyoku}} In 1936, [[NHK]] started radio program {{nihongo|"Kokumin Kayō"|国民歌謡|lit. "National Kayō"}} to compete with ''ryūkōka'', which was under the influence of "Ero Guro Nansensu", but it soon began to air [[war song]]s around July 1937.<ref name="aikawa" /> The program was renamed to {{nihongo|"Warera no Uta"|われらのうた|lit. "Our Songs"}} in 1941 and then {{nihongo|"Kokumin Gasshō"|国民合唱|lit. "National Group Singing"}} in 1942.<ref name="aikawa" /> The songs during the war were called {{nihongo|"Senji Kayō"|戦時歌謡}}. During the war, many musicians were forced to write war songs. [[Yuji Koseki]] composed many war songs and was later criticised as a war collaborator, though he seemed to be touched with remorse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia-songs.co.jp/composer/koseki.html|title=Yuji Koseki|publisher=[[Columbia Music Entertainment]]|accessdate=2009-02-08|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220081514/http://www.columbia-songs.co.jp/composer/koseki.html|archivedate=2012-02-20|df=}}</ref> Koseki composed {{nihongo|"[[Roei no Uta]]"|露営の歌|lit. "Song of the Camp"}} released in 1937. Although the song was a [[B-side]] song, it sold 600,000 copies.<ref>Craig, Timothy J. and King, Richard ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=s4LR2X1rIIEC&pg=PA235 Global Goes Local: Popular Culture in Asia]''. ''[[Google Books]]''. via Hong Kong University Press. 2002. 235. {{ISBN|978-962-209-591-5}}</ref> The 1937 song {{nihongo|"[[Aikoku Kōshinkyoku]]"|愛国行進曲|lit. "Patriotic March"}} sold 1,000,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fma.co.jp/pc/program/morning/today/0925/index.html|title=September 25|publisher=FM Aichi|accessdate=2009-02-20|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924013954/http://www.fma.co.jp/pc/program/morning/today/0925/index.html|archivedate=2015-09-24|df=}}</ref> However, Japanese jazz musicians such as [[Ryoichi Hattori]] seemed to be vigorless to compose war songs.<ref name="sakuramo">{{cite web|url=http://www.sakuramo.to/kuuseki/115.html|title=Song and War: No. 14|publisher=Tomio Sakuramoto|date=2003-08-22|accessdate=2009-01-21|language=ja}}</ref> His son [[Katsuhisa Hattori]] claimed that he was not an antinationalist and he technically were hardly not able to compose war songs even if they wanted to make those because Japanese war songs were musically ''[[enka]]''.<ref name="sakuramo" />
[[File:Announcement ceremony of Taisei-yokusan no Uta.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Recital of "The Song of [[Taisei Yokusankai|Taisei Yokusan]]" in 1940]] On the other hand, former enka-shi [[Haruo Oka]]'s debut song {{nihongo|"Kokkyō no Haru"|国境の春|lit. "Spring at the Border"}} was released in 1939. [[Yoshio Tabata]] also mede his debut with song {{nihongo|"Shima no Funauta"|島の舟唄|lit. "Island Ship Song"}} in 1939. ''[[Rōkyoku]]'' (''naniwa-bushi'') was used for enhancing the national prestige.<ref name="nishinippon">{{cite web|url=http://www.nishinippon.co.jp/nnp/culture/kayou/20061220/20061220_001.shtml |script-title=ja:第６部・演歌巡礼＜８＞初代桃中軒雲右衛門 受け継がれゆく浪花節 |publisher=[[Nishinippon Shimbun]] |date=2006-12-20 |accessdate=2009-02-02 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207014456/http://www.nishinippon.co.jp/nnp/culture/kayou/20061220/20061220_001.shtml |archivedate=2009-02-07 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:二葉あき子.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Akiko Futaba]], who sang "Kōgen no Tsuki"]] Although many war songs were made after the beginning of the [[Pacific War]], {{nihongo|"Kōgen no Tsuki"|高原の月|lit. "Tableland Moon"}}, sung by Noboru Kirishima and [[Akiko Futaba]], became popular as a lyrical song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0609/0609261828/1.php|script-title=ja:太平洋戦争中の歌謡曲|publisher=[[JANJAN]]|date=2006-09-28|accessdate=2009-05-09|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080928011608/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0609/0609261828/1.php|archivedate=2008-09-28|df=}}</ref> When the war was nearing an end, the theme included frightful spectacles such as the [[Battle of Attu]], [[Guadalcanal Campaign]] and [[Gilbert and Marshall Islands campaign|Marshall Islands Campaign]].<ref name="sakuramo" /> Oka went to [[Ambon Island]], but fell ill and soon returned to Japan. [[Bin Uehara]], who used ''kobushi'' of ''naniwa-bushi'' for singing, was killed in the [[New Guinea campaign]] and Fujiyama was taken prisoner in [[Indonesia]].<ref name="warend">{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0610/0610042198/1.php |script-title=ja:名歌手たち、それぞれの終戦 |publisher=[[JANJAN]] |date=2006-10-05 |accessdate=2009-02-07 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080928014036/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0610/0610042198/1.php |archivedate=2008-09-28 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:林伊佐緒.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Isao Hayashi]], the composer for military song "Shussei Heishi o Okuru Uta"]] After the war, the songs during the war have been regarded as a taboo even in Japan despite those historical importance.<ref name="aikawa" /> One of war songs, {{nihongo|"[[Shussei Heishi o Okuru Uta]]"|出征兵士を送る歌|literally "Song for giving warriors a send-off"}}, composed by [[Isao Hayashi]], went on to become a theme of Japanese right-wing groups called ''[[uyoku dantai]]''.<ref name="sakuramo" /> [[Li Xianglan]]'s "Suzhou Nocturne", composed by Hattori, has remained controversial in China, though it was a non-propaganda song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0WDP/is_/ai_55496549|title=China's wartime history still haunts popular theme song|publisher=[[BNET]]. via Asian Economic News|date=1999-08-16|accessdate=2009-01-27}}</ref> After the war, [[Taro Shoji]], who heard the [[Gyokuon-hōsō]] in [[Nagano Prefecture]], was once banned from singing many of his songs because those were regarded as nationalistic.<ref name="warend" /> ''Rōkyoku'' faded into the wallpaper with the spread of television in the postwar period.<ref name="nishinippon" /> In 1946, NHK revived their music program as "Radio Kayō" and it was later reformed as "[[Minna no Uta]]", but NHK was disinclined to mention its former history.<ref name="aikawa" />
===1945–1954: Postwar popularity=== [[File:岡晴夫.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Haruo Oka]], who sang "Akogare no Hawaii kōro"]] {{see also|Japanese jazz}} [[Michiko Namiki]]'s song {{nihongo|"Ringo no Uta"|リンゴの唄|lit. "Song of Apple"}}sung by Michiko Namiki and Noboru Kirishima, airing in 1945 movie "Soyokaze", became popular. Haruo Oka also released hit songs such as his 1946 song {{nihongo|"Tokyo no Hanauri Musume"|東京の花売り娘|lit. "Tokyo Flower Girl"}} and his 1948 song {{nihongo|"Akogare no Hawaii kōro"|憧れのハワイ航路|lit. "Coveted Fairway to Hawaii"}}. Ichiro Fujiyama, who was falsely reported to have been killed in battle, returned to Japan in 1946.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0611/0611013832/1.php|script-title=ja:戦後歌謡の復活・戦前派歌手の活躍|publisher=[[JANJAN]]|date=2006-11-02|accessdate=2009-02-12|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110184534/http://www.news.janjan.jp/column/0611/0611013832/1.php|archivedate=2007-11-10|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Ginza KanKan Musume.jpg|thumb|left|170px|Jazz singer [[Shizuko Kasagi]] and actress [[Hideko Takamine]]]] Ryoichi Hattori, who moved to [[Shanghai]] in 1944, contributed to advancing Japanese ''poppusu'' music after the war.<ref name="fujitv" /> [[Shizuko Kasagi]]'s 1947 song "Tokyo Boogie-Woogie", composed by Hattori, became popular. Hattori also composed [[Ichimaru]]'s 1949 song "Shamisen Boogie-Woogie". Around that time, [[Hibari Misora]] became known as an [[impersonator]] of Kasagi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://showa.mainichi.jp/news/1947/10/post-fcec.html|script-title=ja:「東京ブギウギ」大ヒット|publisher=Mainichi Shimbun|accessdate=2009-04-12|language=ja}}</ref> She made her debut with song "Kappa Boogie-Woogie" in 1949. Hattori's composed song {{nihongo|"Aoi Sanmyaku"|青い山脈|lit. "Blue Mountains"}}, which was sung by Ichiro Fujiyama and Mitsue Nara, became a major hit in the early post-war years in Japan.<ref name="fujitv" />
Yuji Koseki composed {{nihongo|"Nagasaki no Kane"|長崎の鐘|lit. "The Bells of [[Nagasaki]]"}} and {{nihongo|"Himeyuri no Tō"|ひめゆりの塔|lit. "[[Himeyuri students|Himeyuri]] Lily Tower"}}.<ref name="koseki">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B00005EP2Z|script-title=ja:古関裕而歌曲集/長崎の鐘~新しき朝の|publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.jp]]|accessdate=2009-02-07|language=ja}}</ref> "Nagasaki no Kane", based on [[Takashi Nagai]]'s book ''[[The Bells of Nagasaki]]'', was sung by Fujiyama in 1949. Fujiyama became the final singer of all singers at the 1st [[Kōhaku Uta Gassen]] with "Nagasaki no Kane" in 1951. [[Chiemi Eri]] debuted in 1952 and [[Izumi Yukimura]] debuted in 1953. Fujiyama moved to [[NHK]] in 1954 and returned to his original style―classical music. He went on to become a [[conducting|conductor]] for "[[Hotaru no Hikari]]" at the [[Kōhaku Uta Gassen]].<ref name="hotarunohikari">{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/domariko/40746/|script-title=ja:紅白「蛍の光」3代目指揮に平尾昌晃さん|publisher=Oricon|date=2006-12-26|accessdate=2009-02-08|language=ja}}</ref>
===1955–1963: Transformation of music===
{{main|Kayōkyoku}} New singers such as [[Hibari Misora]], [[Hachiro Kasuga]], [[Michiya Mihashi]] and [[Chiyoko Shimakura]] became popular when old singers became unpopular.<ref name="elekitel4" /> The period between around 1955 and 1964 saw the popularity of "[[kayōkyoku]]".<ref name="asahi">{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.co.jp/call3/diary/yamaken/essay_29.html |script-title=ja:雑感・戦後日本の世相と流行歌（29） |publisher=[[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=2009-01-27 |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206210117/http://www.asahi.co.jp/call3/diary/yamaken/essay_29.html |archivedate=2009-02-06 |df= }}</ref> Around that time, Japanese composers went on to establish their own genres such as [[Toru Funamura]] and [[Minoru Endo]]'s "Enka", [[Tadashi Yoshida]]'s "Mood Kayō", and [[Hachidai Nakamura]] and [[Hiroshi Miyagawa]]'s "Jazz".<ref name="miyagawa" /> [[Masao Koga]] renounced his pre-war musical style, approaching Hibari Misora.<ref name="elekitel4" />
The song "Otomisan" was made for being sung by Haruo Oka, but was eventually sung by [[Hachiro Kasuga]] and became a major hit in Japan in 1954. The single sold over one million copies.<ref name="kasugahachiro">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntv.co.jp/omoii-tv/today/081022.html|title=The day that enka singer Hachiro Kasuga died|publisher=[[Nippon Television]]|date=2008-10-22|accessdate=2009-04-22|language=ja}}</ref> The song was composed by [[Masanobu Tokuchi]], who came from the [[Ryukyu Islands]]. Kasuga's 1955 song "Wakare no Ipponsugi", composed by Funamura, also became a hit song. Funamura also composed [[Michiya Mihashi]]'s 1955 song "Anoko Ga Naiteru Hatoba". ''Ryōkyōku'' singers such as [[Haruo Minami]] and [[Hideo Murata]] joined Japanese popular music. Hachiro Kasuga, Michiya Mihashi and Hideo Murata went on to form their genre later called ''enka''.<ref name="kasugahachiro" />
[[File:Kyu school band.PNG|thumb|left|225px|[[Kyu Sakamoto]] and his school band]] [[Frank Nagai]]'s 1957 song "[[Yūrakuchō de Aimashō]]", composed by Yoshida, also became popular. Around that time, however, Japanese [[rock and roll]] movement began and the [[Nichigeki Western Carnival]] was opened in 1958. The concerts were taken part in by future popular singers such as [[Mickey Curtis]] and [[Kyu Sakamoto]]. Against Japanese rock and roll movement, [[Yukio Hashi]] shocked Japanese popular music as a young ''enka'' singer because singers of the genre were elderly singers such as Hachiro Kasuga and Michiya Mihashi.<ref name="elekitel4" />
Japanese singers such as Kyu Sakamoto, [[The Peanuts]] and [[Mieko Hirota]] covered American songs at first, but they began to sing their own song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rakuten.ne.jp/gold/cfc-co/showahibari/bk/bk_spe050428b.html|title=ジャパンポップスの黄金時代 (Japan poppusu's golden age)|publisher=Columbia Music Entertainment|date=2005-04-28|accessdate=2009-01-29|language=ja}}</ref> Sakamoto's 1961 single "[[Sukiyaki (song)|Ue o muite arukō]]", composed by Nakamura, became a major hit in Japan. On the other hand, Hideo Murata's 1961 single {{nihongo|"Ōsho"|王将|lit. "King General"}}, composed by Toru Funamura, sold over one million copies in Japan. On June 5, 1962, [[Saburō Kitajima]] made his debut with the single "Bungacha Bushi." Funamura composed Kitajima's 1962 hit song {{nihongo|"Namida Bune"|なみだ船|lit. "Boat of Tears"}}. Hiroshi Miyagawa composed The Peanuts' 1962 song "Furimukanaide." The Peanuts also sang "[[Mothra]]'s Song". The song was composed by Yuji Koseki.<ref name="koseki" />
In 1963, the era of former popular singers such as [[Hibari Misora]], [[Chiemi Eri]], [[Izumi Yukimura]], [[Hachiro Kasuga]], [[Michiya Mihashi]] and [[Frank Nagai]] seemed to end and Sakamoto released a Japanese hit song titled "[[Miagete Goran Yoru no Hoshi o]]".<ref name="yamaken20">{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.co.jp/call3/diary/yamaken/essay_20.html|script-title=ja:雑感・戦後日本の世相と流行歌（20）|publisher=[[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=2009-01-28|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215215232/http://www.asahi.co.jp/call3/diary/yamaken/essay_20.html|archivedate=2012-02-15|df=}}</ref> In June 1963, Sakamoto's "Ue o muite arukō" reached the number-one position in the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] under its alternative title "Sukiyaki". In 1963, Kitajima's song {{nihongo|"Guitar Jingi"|ギター仁義|lit. "Guitar Benevolence and Righteousness"}} and [[Kazuo Funaki]]'s song {{nihongo|"Koko San Nen Sei"|高校三年生|lit. "High School Seniors"}} also became popular. Both songs were composed by Minoru Endo. Hashi and Funaki became singers for youth music, making a new genre called {{nihongo|"Seishun Kayō"|青春歌謡|lit. "Youthful Kayō"}}.<ref name="elekitel4" />
===1963–1966: Enka's independence and collapse=== {{main|Enka|Group Sounds|J-pop}} On September 6, 1963, record label [[Nippon Crown]] became independent from the [[Nippon Columbia]]. [[Saburō Kitajima]] was its member. [[Hibari Misora]] presented a song titled "Kanto Harusame Kasa" when the record label was established.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crownmusic.co.jp/publish/1963.html|title=1963|publisher=Crown Music|accessdate=2009-01-28|language=ja}}</ref> Kitajima took part in the Kōhaku Uta Gassen for the first time on December 31, 1963. The audience share of the 14th [[Kōhaku Uta Gassen]] reached 81.4% in 1963.<ref name="yamaken20" /> In 1964, Haruo Minami released his cover version of song {{nihongo|"Tokyo Gorin Ondo"|東京五輪音頭|lit. "[[Ondo (music)|Ondo]] for the [[1964 Summer Olympics|Tokyo Olympics]]"}}, composed by [[Masao Koga]]. In 1965, Kitajima released a string of hits such as {{nihongo|"Kyōdai Jingi"|兄弟仁義|lit. "Brother Benevolence And Righteousness"}}, {{nihongo|"Kaerokana"|帰ろかな|lit. "Maybe I Will Return to My Home"}} and {{nihongo|"Hakodate no Hito"|函館の女|lit. "Hakodate Woman"}}. "Kaerokana" was composed by [[Hachidai Nakamura]]. Koga composed Hibari's song "Yawara", which won the grand prix award at the [[Japan Record Award]] in 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.city.okawa.fukuoka.jp/kogakinen/profile.html|title=Koga Masao Profile|publisher=Koga Masao Memorial Hall|accessdate=2009-02-03|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150320070312/http://www.city.okawa.fukuoka.jp/kogakinen/profile.html|archivedate=2015-03-20|df=}}</ref> Koga was also an original composer of Hibari's 1966 cover song {{nihongo|"Kanashii Sake"|悲しい酒|lit. "Sad Sake"}}. His music, called "Koga melody", became a base of modern ''enka'' and he became known as "the father of modern ''enka''".<ref>Christine Reiko Yano. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=SnGY9XQj0ocC&pg=PA36 Tears of Longing: Nostalgia and the Nation in Japanese Popular Song]''. ''[[Google Books]]''. via Harvard Univ Asia Center. 2003. 36. {{ISBN|978-0-674-01276-9}}</ref>
On the other hand, Hachidai Nakamura also composed the [[Johnnys]]' 1964 debut single "Wakai Namida." Japanese guitarist [[Yūzō Kayama]] also produced his 1965 hit song "Kimi to Itsumademo" as a singer. British rock band [[The Beatles]] visited Japan and had a concert at the [[Nippon Budokan]] in 1966. With the aim of breaking the traditional style, [[Group Sounds]] band The Blue Comets' 1966 song {{nihongo|"Aoi Hitomi"|青い瞳|lit. "Blue Eye"}}, originally released as an English song, was released as a Japanese song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://columbia.jp/~bluecomets/disco.html|title=The Blue Comets' Discography|publisher=[[Columbia Music Entertainment]]|accessdate=2009-04-22|language=ja}}</ref> In 1966, folk singer [[Ryoko Moriyama]], a daughter of jazz musician Hisashi Moriyama, also released hit song {{nihongo|"Kyō no Hi wa Sayōnara"|今日の日はさようなら|lit. "Good-bye, Today"}}. The Blue Comets' song "Blue Chateau" won the grand prix award at the Japan Record Award in 1967. [[The Folk Crusaders]]' 1967 song "I Only Live Twice" also had a big impact on Japanese popular music. New musical movement called {{nihongo|"Kayō Pops"|歌謡ポップス}} also a string of hits such as [[Ayumi Ishida (actress)|Ayumi Ishida]]'s 1968 song "Blue Light Yokohama", composed by Kyohei Tsutsumi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.co.jp/call3/diary/yamaken/essay_25.html|script-title=ja:雑感・戦後日本の世相と流行歌（25）|publisher=[[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=2009-04-30|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215215248/http://www.asahi.co.jp/call3/diary/yamaken/essay_25.html|archivedate=2012-02-15|df=}}</ref>
Group Sounds became unpopular in the late 1960s in Japan. Then, Group Sounds was displaced by "New Rock" in Japanese underground rock music around 1970. Japanese-language rock band [[Happy End (band)|Happy End]] became one of prototypes of modern [[J-pop]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/confidence/25384/|script-title=ja:究極のビートルズ来日賞味法！ ビートルズが日本に与えたもの|publisher=Oricon|date=2006-06-21|accessdate=2009-01-29|language=ja}}</ref> Mickey Curtis formed rock band "Samurai" in 1969 in U.K. and later scouted the Japanese band "Carol" in which leader was [[Eikichi Yazawa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/entertainment/special/2008kekon/KFullNormal20080218036.html|script-title=ja:古希目前ミッキー・カーチス33歳差婚|publisher=Sponichi|date=2008-02-18|accessdate=2009-03-09|language=ja|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316001830/http://www.sponichi.co.jp/entertainment/special/2008kekon/KFullNormal20080218036.html|archivedate=2008-03-16|df=}}</ref>
==Legacy== A part of Ryoichi Hattori's Western-style music during that period remained in Western-style [[classical music]] of Japan and was transvalued in 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20020319c3.html|title=Japanese classical composers gaining popularity|publisher=The Japan Times|date=2002-03-19|accessdate=2009-02-08}}</ref> His [[tribute album]] was released on October 17, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yesasia.com/us/ryoichi-hattori-tanjo-100-shunen-kinen-tribute-album-japan-version/1005017574-0-0-0-en/info.html|title=Ryoichi Hattori - Tanjo 100 Shunen Kinen Tribute Album (Japan Version)|publisher=[[YesAsia]]|accessdate=2009-02-07}}</ref> Various musicians such as [[Hideaki Tokunaga]] (for "Wakare no Blues"), [[Kazumasa Oda]] (for "Suzhou Nocturne"), [[Masaharu Fukuyama]] (for "Tokyo Boogie-woogie") and [[Tokyo Ska Paradise Orchestra]] (for "[[Aoi sanmyaku (1949 film)|Aoi Sanmyaku]]") took part in the album. The tribute album debuted at the number-ten position on the Japanese [[Oricon]] weekly album charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/rankmusic/48971/|script-title=ja:服部良一、生誕100周年記念作で作家史上初の快挙！|publisher=Oricon|date=2007-10-23|accessdate=2009-10-02|language=ja}}</ref>
==Notable ryūkōka singers== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Noriko Awaya]] *[[Ichiro Fujiyama]] *[[Akiko Futaba]] *[[Teiichi Futamura]] *[[Katuhiko Haida]] *[[Isao Hayashi]] *[[Ichimaru]] *[[Hanko Kagurazaka]] *[[Katsutaro Kouta]] *[[Haruo Minami]] *[[Dick Mine]] *[[Hibari Misora]]<ref>http://www.discogs.com/ja/artist/530632-Hibari-Misora</ref> *[[Haruo Oka]] *[[Taro Shoji]] *[[Bin Uehara]] *[[Hamako Watanabe]] {{div col end}}
==See also== * [[J-pop]] * [[Enka]] * [[Trot (music)|Trot]] * [[Taiwanese pop]]
==Footnotes== {{reflist|1|group=fn}}

revision.text:
{{Cleanup rewrite|date=June 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Culture of India}} India is home to a diverse population playing many different kinds of sports across the country. [[Cricket]] is the most popular sport in [[India]]. [[Field hockey]] is the most successful sport for India at Olympics in which India has won eight [[Olympic medal|Olympic gold medals]]. [[Kabaddi]] is the most popular indigenous sport in the country. Other popular sports in India are [[badminton]], [[Association football|football]], [[basketball]], [[chess]], [[shooting]], [[wrestling]], [[boxing]], [[tennis]], [[Squash (sport)|squash]], [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]], [[gymnastics]], [[Sport of athletics|athletics]] and [[table tennis]]. Some indigenous sports are also popular in India such as [[Kho-kho]], [[Kabaddi]], [[Fighter kite]], [[Polo]] and [[Gillidanda]] among others. There are some popular sports which has originated in India such as [[Chess]], [[Snooker]] and [[Kabbadi]]. India has won Olympic medals in [[Badminton]], [[Wrestling]], [[Shooting]], [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]], [[Boxing]] and [[Tennis]]. India has also won World Cups in [[Cricket]], [[Field Hockey]] and [[Kabbadi]]. India has hosted and co-hosted several international sporting events including the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]], the [[1951 Asian Games|1951]] and [[1982 Asian Games]], the [[1987 South Asian Games|1987]], [[1995 South Asian Games|1995]] and [[2016 South Asian Games]], the [[1987 Cricket World Cup|1987]], [[1996 Cricket World Cup|1996]], [[2011 Cricket World Cup]] and [[2016 ICC World Twenty20]], the [[2003 Afro-Asian Games]], the [[1989 Asian Athletics Championships|1989]], [[2013 Asian Athletics Championships|2013]] and [[2017 Asian Athletics Championships]], the [[1982 Men's Hockey World Cup|1982]] and [[2010 Men's Field hockey World Cup]], [[2016–17 Men's FIH Hockey World League]], the [[1979 Asian Wrestling Championships|1979]], [[1987 Asian Wrestling Championships|1987]], [[1991 Asian Wrestling Championships|1991]], [[2003 Asian Wrestling Championships|2003]], [[2010 Asian Wrestling Championships|2010]], [[2013 Asian Wrestling Championships|2013]] and [[2017 Asian Wrestling Championships]], the [[2009 BWF World Championships]], the [[2004 Kabaddi World Cup (Standard style)|2004]], [[2007 Kabaddi World Cup (Standard style)|2007]] and [[2016 Kabaddi World Cup (Standard style)]], the 1980,1992 and 2009 [[Asian Table Tennis Championships]], the [[1981 ABC Championship]], the [[2009 FIBA Asia Championship for Women]], the 1989, [[2005 Asian Cycling Championships|2005]], [[2013 Asian Cycling Championships|2013]] and [[2017 Asian Cycling Championships]]. India has recently hosted the [[2017 FIBA Women's Asia Cup]], the [[2017 FIFA U-17 World Cup]], the [[2017 ISSF World Cup]] and will host the [[2018 Men's Hockey World Cup]]. India has some premier domestic leagues in different sports which are very popular in the country. [[Indian Premier League]] (IPL) is a premier [[Twenty20]] & the most popular cricket league in the world held every year since 2008. The [[I-League]] and [[Indian Super League]] are premier football league tournaments held since 2007 and 2014 respectively, the [[Pro Kabaddi]] league is the most popular indigenous league in the country held since 2014, the [[Hockey India League]] is the premier hockey league held since 2013, the [[Premier Badminton League]] is the badminton premier league held since 2013, the [[Pro Wrestling League]] premier Wrestling league held since 2015 and [https://www.ultimatetabletennis.in/ Ultimate Table Tennis] league held since 2017. Major international sporting events annually held in India include the [[Chennai Open]] in tennis, the [[Indian Masters]] in golf, the [[India Open]] since 2008 and [[Royal Indian Open]] since 2001 in badminton. From 2011 to 2013, India hosted the [[Indian Grand Prix]] Formula 1 race at the [[Buddh International Circuit]], [[Greater Noida]]. The [[National Games of India]] is a national domestic sports event which has been held in the country since 1924 and for developing multi-sports culture in India [[Khelo India School Games]], an event for under-17 school kids, had been started from 2018 as its first edition. ==History== ===Before independence=== The geography of sports in India dates back to the [[Vedas|Vedic]] era. Physical culture in ancient India was fuelled by religious rights. The [[mantra]] in the [[Atharvaveda]], says, "Duty is in my right hand and the fruits of victory in my left." In terms of an ideal, these words hold the same sentiments as the traditional [[Olympic Oath]]: "For the Honour of my Country and the Glory of Sport.Sharma Sushant, https://www.sportskeeda.com/cricket/sports-fanaticism-in-india-history-and-where-are-we-today" Badminton probably originated in India as a grownup's version of a very old children's game known in England as [[battledore and shuttlecock]], the battledore being a paddle and the shuttlecock a small feathered cork, now usually called a "bird." Games like [[chess|chess (chaturanga)]], [[Snooker]] [[snakes and ladders]], playing [[Playing card|cards]], originated in India, and it was from here that these games were transmitted to foreign countries, where they were further modernised. ===After independence=== India hosted the [[Asian Games]] in New Delhi in 1951 and 1982. The [[Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports (India)|Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports]] was initially set up as the Department of Sports in 1982 at the time of organisation of the IX Asian Games in New Delhi. Its name was changed to the Department of Youth Affairs & Sports during celebration of the [[International Youth Year]] in 1985.{{cite web|url=http://yas.nic.in/index.asp?layid=2 |title=Department of Sports |publisher=YAS |date= |accessdate=1 August 2010}} India has also hosted or co-hosted several international sporting events, including the [[1987 Cricket World Cup|1987]] and [[1996 Cricket World Cup]], the [[2003 Afro-Asian Games]], the [[2010 Men's Hockey World Cup|2010 Hockey World Cup]], and the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]]. Major international sporting events annually held in India include the [[Chennai Open]], [[Mumbai Marathon]], [[Delhi Half Marathon]], and the [[Indian Masters]]. The country co-hosted the 1987, 1996, 2011 Cricket World Cup and the first [[Indian Grand Prix]] in 2011. ==Administration and funding== Political responsibility for sport in India is with the Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports, which is headed by a cabinet minister and managed by National Sport Federations.{{cite web|url=http://yas.nic.in/writereaddata/linkimages/8940703031.htm |title=S |publisher=Yas.nic.in |date= |accessdate=1 August 2010}} The only major exception is the BCCI which is the administrative body of Cricket, is not a NSF. Presently there are more than 70 recognised national sports federations (NSF), of which 38 have politicians at the helm.http://www.cppr.in/article/government-is-a-spoilsport/ [[Sports Authority of India]], the field arm of the Ministry, supports and nurtures talent in youth, and provides them with requisite infrastructure, equipment, coaching facilities and competition exposure.{{cite web|url=http://sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in/ |title=Sports Authority of India, Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports – Government of India |publisher=Sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in |date= |accessdate=1 August 2010}} [[Dorabji Tata]], with the support of Dr. A.G. Noehren, then director of [[YMCA]], established the [[Indian Olympic Association]] (IOA) in 1927. IOA is responsible for the Indian continent's participation in the [[Olympic Games]], [[Commonwealth Games]], [[Asian Games]] (outdoor, indoor and beach), and [[South Asian Games]]. Each Olympic and non-Olympic sport has a federation at the national level.{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.ind.in/ioa_history.html |title=Indian Olympic Association |publisher=Olympic.ind.in |date= |accessdate=1 August 2010}} The selection of the national teams is done by the respective national federations and then recommend to IOA for official sponsorship for participation in the games conducted under the auspices of the [[International Olympic Committee]], [[Olympic Council of Asia]], [[Commonwealth Games Federation]], and SAG. A special feature of the Indian Olympic Association is that the National Federations and the State Olympic Associations are affiliated with and recognised by it. The main task of the State Olympic Associations is to promote the Olympic sport and to ensure co-ordination among the State Sports Associations. In 2010–11, the total budget for sports and physical education schemes is {{INRConvert|31177|m}}.http://yas.nic.in/writereaddata/linkimages/6831719428.pdf [[Field hockey|Hockey]], in which India has an impressive record with eight Olympic gold medals, is said to be the national sport.{{cite web|url= https://docs.google.com/document/d/1EAyDe2XtOq4sXlmsK4ONzuYRmJ-hpXaZQuYXxWya9dQ/pub/ |title=1.Dr. RAMAKRISHNAN .K.S. 2 VIDYALAXMI V 3 Dr. SARATHBABU.V. "DEVELOPMENT SPORTS PROFESSION AS A LIFE TIME PROFESSIONAL CAREER IN SPORTS – A PROSPECTIVE STUDY." Shodh Sangam 2.special (2012): 248-255–Uttar Pradesh, India |publisher=http://shodhsangam.org/article/january-2012-special-issue-volume-2/8.html|date= |accessdate=13 May 2015}} The [[Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna]] and the [[Arjuna Award]] are India's highest awards for achievement in sports, while the [[Dronacharya Award]] is awarded for excellence in coaching. India has been criticised for neglecting women in sports, as depicted in the film "[[Chak De! India]]", where women's sports associations are under-sponsored and out of funds. ==International sports events held in India== Following is a list of international sports events held in India: {|
