{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use British English|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Still Open All Hours | image = Still Open All Hours Title Card.jpg | caption = Opening titles | genre = [[Comedy]] | creator = [[Roy Clarke]] | writer = Roy Clarke | director = Dewi Humphreys | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[David Jason]] * [[James Baxter (actor)|James Baxter]] * [[Lynda Baron]] * [[Stephanie Cole]] * [[Maggie Ollerenshaw]] * [[Brigit Forsyth]] * [[Johnny Vegas]] * [[Kulvinder Ghir]] * [[Nina Wadia]] * [[Sally Lindsay]] * [[Tim Healy (actor)|Tim Healy]] }} | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 5 | num_episodes = 34 | list_episodes = List_of_Still_Open_All_Hours_episodes | producer = [[Gareth Edwards (producer)|Gareth Edwards]] | location = [[Dock10 (television facility)|Dock10]], [[MediaCityUK]] (2013)
[[Teddington Studios]] (2014)
[[Pinewood Studios]] (2015—) | runtime = 30 minutes | company = [[BBC]] | distributor = [[BBC Worldwide]]
[[2entertain]]
[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] (Australia, home video) | channel = [[BBC One]] | picture_format = 1080i (16:9 HDTV) | audio_format = Dolby Digital 5.1 | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|12|26|df=y}} | last_aired = present| preceded_by = ''[[Open All Hours]]'' | related = ''[[Seven of One]]'' | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04xd2nw | website_title = ''Still Open All Hours'' at BBC Comedy }} '''''Still Open All Hours''''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] sitcom created by [[Roy Clarke]] for the BBC set in [[Balby]], Doncaster, starring [[David Jason]]. It is the sequel to the sitcom ''[[Open All Hours]]'', which both Clarke and Jason worked on throughout its 26 episode run from 1973 to 1985, following a 40th Anniversary Special in December 2013 commemorating the original series.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a521620/sir-david-jason-to-star-in-open-all-hours-christmas-special.html|title=Sir David Jason to star in 'Open All Hours' Christmas special|last=Goodacre|first=Kate|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=7 October 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}} Like the original series, the story focuses on the life of Granville as he continues to run his uncle Arkwright's shop, with the assistance of his son Leroy, while seeking to be with his love interest. Unlike the original series, the cast includes a more regular group of characters and additional side-plots concerning them, and features the return of [[Lynda Baron]], [[Stephanie Cole]], and [[Maggie Ollerenshaw]] as their respective characters in ''Open All Hours''. Following the 2013 special, the show has run five full-length series, with the first of them premiering on 26 December 2014. ==Premise== Set within the same small grocer's shop in [[Balby]], a suburb of [[Doncaster]] in [[South Yorkshire]], the show focuses on the life of [[Granville (Open All Hours)|Granville]] ([[David Jason]]), now much older and the owner of [[Arkwright (Open All Hours)|Arkwright]]'s shop since his uncle's death. Despite his youth's lacklustre social life, Granville has since grown into the same person as his uncle, having been taught by him over how to sell to customers. To assist him with the running of his shop is Leroy ([[James Baxter (actor)|James Baxter]]), Granville's son from one of his previous girlfriends, who maintains a rather robust love life with several girls but struggles to cope with the work and sales approach of his father. Like his uncle, Granville maintains a love life with Mavis ([[Maggie Ollerenshaw]]), an absent-minded but sweet woman who loves him in return, but who lives across the road alongside her sister Madge ([[Brigit Forsyth]]), a miserable woman who does not like men and chooses to keep Mavis from following a relationship with Granville. Both are regulars to the shop, alongside others from the neighbourhood whom Granville tries to offload products onto, which he has bought and had little success to sell on. ==Characters== {{Main article|List of Open All Hours characters}} ===Granville=== {{Main article|Granville (Open All Hours)|l1=Granville}} Since ''Open All Hours'', having lived his youth as a nice, yet shy and awkward man who struggled with shop life, Granville has changed into a more toned-down version of his uncle Arkwright, who thanks to his uncle's training, now exhibits a similar manner of selling goods at inflated prices, fabricating stories to sell useless and/or unsalable items to hapless customers, and keeping a close watch on the money he spends, often through employing the use of a special money belt that cause slight issues and embarrassment at times. During his uncle's training, Granville engaged in relationships with several girlfriends, in which a fling in Blackpool resulted in the procreation of his son Leroy, whom he was left in charge of by his mother. Following his uncle's death, Granville inherited his shop, which he runs alongside Leroy, often teasing his son over the identity of his mother, secretly concealing the fact he knows who it is, while subjecting him to practical jokes and teaching him some of the tricks that his uncle taught him. In ''Still Open All Hours'', he maintains a belief that his uncle lives on through the shop's till, often referring to it as Arkwright in later episodes, due to the nature of it opening up or closing shut suddenly at times for various reasons, such as when there is mention of spending considerable money on something. Like his uncle, Granville has a love interest of his own within Mavis, a woman he met during his youth and whom he still fondly loves. Unlike his uncle, Granville struggles to be with Mavis since the end of her previous marriage, due to her sister Madge desiring to keep them apart. To try to keep Madge distracted and hopefully remove her as an obstacle, Granville spends his time grooming one of his regulars, Gastric, into becoming Madge's love interest. In later episodes, he also finds himself trying to stop the advances of widower Delphine Featherstone, one of his uncle's customers whom he accidentally sent a love note to that was meant for Mavis, by convincing a fellow widower, Wilburn Newbold, into entering a relationship with her and maintaining it, despite Mrs Featherstone's presence unnerving him. ===Leroy=== Leroy was born to a mother whom his father met during a fling in Blackpool, but whom he does not know about, despite Granville secretly knowing who she is; although his mother is talked about during the first series, including a visit by her to see Leroy, references about her become rare and non-existent in later episodes. Left into his father's care by his mother at a young age, Leroy suffers similar issues like Granville did in his youth, such as having to be up early to open the shop and thus being on the receiving end of his father's practical jokes, and handling the deliveries of purchases to customers. Unlike his father, Leroy maintains an active social life with many young women, most having boyfriends that they don't mind ignoring to spend time with him, much to his father's dismay, while displaying a firm dislike of his father's practices for unloading products he buys cheaply but cannot sell. By the fourth series, Leroy becomes committed to winning the affection of a local librarian, despite her values and her lifestyle as a vegan. ===Main=== {| class="wikitable planrowheaders" style="width: 80%; margin-right: 0;" |- !rowspan="2" width="30%"|Character !rowspan="2" width="30%"|Played by !colspan="6" width="30%"|[[List of Still Open All Hours episodes|Series]] !rowspan="2"|Episode count |- ! |- |} ==Episodes== {{Main article|List of Still Open All Hours episodes}} thirty-three episodes of ''Still Open All Hours'', all written by Roy Clarke, have been produced for the BBC. The show began airing on 26 December 2013 with an anniversary special of original series, ''Open All Hours''. All episodes have a running time of 30 minutes. Between ''Open All Hours'' and ''Still Open All Hours'', there has been a total of 59 episodes and nine series broadcast between 1973 and 2018. ==Production== ===Series development=== ''Still Open All Hours'' was broadcast on 26 December 2013, with Jason reprising his role of Granville from ''Open All Hours''. The new one-off episode written by Clarke showed Granville now running the shop with his son Leroy (played by [[James Baxter (actor)|James Baxter]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2509311/Open-All-Hours-returns-filming-kicks-David-Jason.html|title=Look who's the b-b-boss now: Granville pulls on Arkwright's famous brown coat as David Jason returns in Open All Hours after 30 years|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=18 November 2013|accessdate=19 November 2013}} after inheriting it from Arkwright.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-24426296|title=Sir David Jason back for Open All Hours Christmas show|publisher=BBC News|date=7 October 2013|accessdate=8 October 2013}} Clarke wrote the script in two weeks, and production began in October 2013. The exterior scenes were filmed at the original location at Lister Avenue in [[Doncaster]] from 18 to 20 November 2013. The interior scenes were recorded on 3 December 2013 at [[Dock10 (television facility)|dock10]], [[MediaCityUK]] in [[City of Salford|Salford]] in front of a studio audience. A 30-minute documentary accompanying the show's return, entitled ''Open All Hours: A Celebration'', aired on 27 December 2013, the day after the new episode was broadcast, on BBC One.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03n2r55|title=Open All Hours: A Celebration|publisher=BBC|date=15 December 2013|accessdate=15 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/open-all-hours-special-could-lead-to-new-series-1-6252817#.Uosq2FKRTlA.twitter|title=Open All Hours special could lead to new series|publisher=[[Doncaster Free Press]]|date=19 November 2013|accessdate=22 November 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/breaking-new-version-of-open-all-hours-will-be-filmed-in-doncaster-1-6129435|title=BREAKING: New version of Open All Hours will be filmed in Doncaster|publisher=[[Doncaster Free Press]]|date=9 October 2013|accessdate=13 October 2013}} On 30 January 2014, the BBC commissioned ''Still Open All Hours'' for six new episodes beginning on 26 December 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-25963719|title=Still Open All Hours commissioned for full series|publisher=BBC News|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=31 January 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2014-01-30/still-open-all-hours-series-confirmed|title=Still Open All Hours series confirmed|last=Glanfield|first=Tim|work=[[Radio Times]]|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=3 February 2014}} The controller of BBC comedy commissioning, Shane Allen, said: "The resounding success of the Christmas revival showed the huge and enduring audience affection for this much-loved classic. Roy has done a terrific job of updating the characters whilst keeping what was warm-hearted and enjoyable about the world of the original series."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jan/30/bbc-still-open-all-hours-david-jason|title=BBC commissions full series of Still Open All Hours|last=Plunkett|first=John|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=30 January 2014}} Production for series one started in August 2014, exterior filming started on 15 September and location recording was completed on 26 September 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/video-open-all-hours-filming-starts-in-doncaster-1-6840950|title=Video: Open All Hours filming starts in Doncaster|work=[[Doncaster Free Press]]|date=15 September 2014|accessdate=15 September 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/open-all-hours-filming-set-to-end-in-doncaster-1-6864168|title=Open All Hours filming set to end in Doncaster|work=[[Sheffield Star]]|date=26 September 2014|accessdate=29 September 2014}} Interior scenes were recorded in front of a studio audience from 10 October until 21 November 2014 at Teddington Studios.{{cite web|url=http://m.pinewoodgroup.com/production/still-open-all-hours-series-1|title=Still Open All Hours Series 1|work=[[The Pinewood Studios Group]]|date=15 September 2014|accessdate=25 November 2014}} The show later returned for a second series, beginning on 26 December 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.southwales-eveningpost.co.uk/Chuckle-Brothers-Swansea/story-26728178-detail/story.html|title=The Chuckle Brothers: To me, to you... to Swansea!|publisher=South Wales Evening Post|date=19 June 2015|accessdate=19 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/1885/still_open_all_hours_series_2_confirmed/|title=Still Open All Hours series 2 confirmed|work=[[British Comedy Guide]]|date=12 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2016}} with production starting in September 2015. Exterior scenes were filmed on location from 14{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3233987/Sir-David-Jason-75-steps-comedy-character-Granville-films-new-series-BBC-s-Open-Hours-Doncaster.html|title=Sir David Jason, 75, steps out as comedy character Granville as he films new series of BBC's Still Open All Hours in Doncaster|work=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}}-24 September 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3247598/Tim-Healy-gets-spot-bother-dressed-Santa-joins-Sir-David-Jason-set-Open-Hours-Christmas-special.html|title=Tim Healy gets into a spot of bother while dressed as Santa as he joins Sir David Jason on the set of the Still Open All Hours Christmas special|work=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=24 September 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}} Interior scenes were recorded in front of a studio audience at [[Pinewood Studios]] from 9 October until 20 November 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/still-open-all-hours-to-be-filmed-at-world-famous-pinewood-studios-1-7488057|title=Still Open All Hours to be filmed at world famous Pinewood Studios|author=Burke Darren|work=[[Doncaster Free Press]]|date=30 September 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}} In January 2016, [[David Jason]] revealed that a third series would be produced in 2016. The series began airing on 26 December 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/david-jason-confirms-still-open-7215294 | title=David Jason confirms Still Open All Hours will return and reveals his Hollywood dream | publisher=The Mirror | date=20 January 2016 | accessdate=21 January 2016}} Production started in September 2016 with on location for exterior scenes being shot in Balby Doncaster from 12 September 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2016-09-12/david-jason-to-return-for-new-series-of-still-open-all-hours-on-bbc1|title=David Jason to return for new series of Still Open All Hours|last=Staff|first=Radio Times|work=[[Radio Times]]|date=12 September 2016|accessdate=14 September 2016}} [[Lynda Baron]] could not reprise her role as Nurse Gladys Emmanuel as the filming dates clashed with Baron's current contract with ''[[EastEnders]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/showbiz/tv-radio/709858/Still-Open-All-Hours-third-series-WITHOUT-Nurse-Emmanuel|title=Still Open All Hours third series WITHOUT Nurse Emmanuel|last=Crockery|first=Claire|work=[[Daily Express]]|date=12 September 2016|accessdate=15 September 2016}} David Jason announced that a fourth series would be filmed in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/01/14/only-fools-and-horses-reboot-sir-david-jason-says-he-would-play-del-boy-one-last-time-6381461/ | title=Only Fools And Horses reboot? Sir David Jason says he would play Del Boy one last time | publisher=The Mirror | date=14 January 2017 | accessdate=9 February 2017}} Filming began in September 2017 with David Jason seen on location in Doncaster with co-star Tim Healy {{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/david-jason-unrecognisable-sports-bushy-11165965|title=David Jason is unrecognisable as he sports bushy beard for new sitcom series}}. The series began airing on 28 December 2017. {{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/tv-legend-david-jason-mrs-11836202|title=TV legend David Jason: Mrs Brown's Boys is too rude for family audiences | publisher=The Mirror | date=11 January 2018 | accessdate=12 January 2018}}. Interior scenes were recorded at Pinewood Studios in front of a live-studio-audience on 7, 14, and 21 October and on the 4, 11, 18, and 24 November 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/showsandtours/shows/still_open_all_hours_2016|title=Still Open All Hours shows and tours|last=Staff|first=BBC Shows and tours|work=[[BBC]]|date=12 September 2016|accessdate=15 September 2016}} In early 2017 a fourth series was commissioned production started in August 2017. On location exterior scenes for the fourth series commenced on 11 September 2017 in Doncaster.{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/pictures-still-open-all-hours-filming-gets-underway-in-doncaster-but-not-at-arkwright-s-shop-1-8749226|title=PICTURES: Still Open All Hours filming gets underway in Doncaster - but not at Arkwright's shop | publisher=Doncaster Free Press | date=12 September 2016}}. In January 2018, it was revealed the show will return for a fifth series late 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/tv-legend-david-jason-mrs-11836202|title=TV legend David Jason: Mrs Brown's Boys is too rude for family audiences | publisher=The Mirror | date=11 January 2018 | accessdate=12 January 2018}} The fifth series was officially confirmed on 2 May 2018, with filming due to commence in the summer. The series premiere aired on BBC1, on 7 October 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/guide/bbcone/20181007|title=BBC iPlayer - BBC One Guide - Sun Oct 07 2018|work=BBC iPlayer|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-GB}} ===Filming locations=== [[File:Lister Avenue in Balby (a suburb of Doncaster in the North of England), used for the exterior shots on the BBC television sitcom Open All Hours.jpg|thumb|Lister Avenue in [[Balby]] is used for the filming of '' Still Open All Hours''; Boutique on the right doubles as Arkwright's]] The exterior shots reused the original shop from the series, on Lister Avenue in [[Balby]], a suburb of [[Doncaster]]. The shop had to be extensively redressed (for both programmes) to resemble a traditional corner shop, as it has been a hair salon since 1962. This process took two days, before filming on location for three consecutive days.{{cite web|first=David|last=Wilkes|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2450383/Real-life-shops-inspired-BBCs-Open-All-Hours.html|title=The real life shops behind Open All Hours: How a hairdressers and a c-c-convenience store helped inspire the BBC sitcom that is about to be resurrected for Christmas special|publisher=Mail Online|date=19 November 2013|accessdate=6 January 2014}} The studio recordings for the 2013 special were recorded at [[Dock10 (television facility)|dock10]] at [[MediaCityUK]]. For the first series, [[Teddington Studios]] were used and the second, third, and fourth series were all recorded at [[Pinewood Studios]]. {{clear}} ==Broadcast and reception== The special was broadcast on BBC One on 26 December 2013 and received 9.43m (39.9% of the audience) viewers according to overnight figures and was the most watched programme on that day.{{cite web|first=Sam|last=Rigby|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a540642/still-open-all-hours-tops-boxing-day-ratings-with-94m.html|title=Still Open All Hours tops Boxing Day ratings with 9.4m|publisher=Digital Spy|date=27 December 2013|accessdate=4 January 2014}} Final viewing figures showed that it was watched by 12.23m and was the most watched programme for that week.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2013/dec/27/still-open-all-hours-largest-audience-boxing-day|title=Top 30s|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=27 December 2015}} It received generally poor reviews from critics. Will Dean of ''[[The Independent]]'', referencing Arkwright's trademark stutter, called it "a w-w-worthy effort" but criticised the attempt to revive the show without the late [[Ronnie Barker]].{{cite news|first=Will|last=Dean|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/still-open-all-hours-review-it-was-a-wwworthy-effort--but-theres-only-one-arkwright-9026351.html|title=Still Open All Hours review: It was a w-w-worthy effort – but there’s only one Arkwright|publisher=The Independent|date=26 December 2013|accessdate=4 January 2014}} Ben Lawrence of ''[[Telegraph Media Group|The Telegraph]]'' said it "felt like a relic of another era" criticising the jokes and Jason's performance.{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Lawrence|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/10537092/Still-Open-All-Hours-BBC-One-review.html|title=Still Open All Hours, BBC One, review|publisher=The Telegraph|date=26 December 2013|accessdate=4 January 2014}} Jacob Mason, writing on the Radio Times website, described the show as "warmly nostalgic", whilst others noted it as "a fitting tribute to Ronnie Barker".{{cite web|first=Marc|last=Andrews|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2529610/Still-Open-All-Hours-hailed-warmly-nostalgic-fitting-tribute-Ronnie-Barker.html|title=TV viewers hail the one-off return of classic sitcom Open All Hours as 'warmly nostalgic' and 'a fitting tribute to Ronnie Barker'|publisher=Daily Mail|date=26 December 2013|accessdate=4 January 2014}} Jojo Martin praised the show saying " I loved Open All Hours and I love Still Open All Hours even more, Still Open is the one of the best comedy series on our screens". On 21 November 2014, the BBC confirmed that ''Still Open All Hours'' would return for a full series in 2014. This began airing on 26 December 2014 and finished on 25 January 2015. Series 2 began on 26 December 2015 with a run of 6 episodes and finished on 26 January 2016, Season 3 which began airing on 26 December 2016 with 7 episodes, Season 4 which began airing on 28 December 2017, followed by Season 5 starting on 7 October 2018 ==DVD releases== Although filmed and broadcast in High-definition, no Blu-ray releases have been announced to date. Series One and the 2013 Christmas Special was released on DVD on 2 February 2015 by [[2 entertain]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Still-Open-all-Hours-Christmas/dp/B00RCYDMJ8/ref=sr_1_2?s=dvd&ie=UTF8&qid=1419349139&sr=1-2&keywords=still+open+all+hours|title=Still Open All Hours Series One + 2013 Christmas Special [DVD]|work=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.uk]]|date=23 December 2014|accessdate=23 December 2014}} Series 2 was released on 1 February 2016. Series 3 was released on 13 February 2017. {{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B01NBNAPHN/ref=sr_1_19?s=dvd&ie=UTF8&qid=1482514168&sr=1-19&keywords=still+open+all+hours |title=Still Open All Hours: Series Three + 2016 Christmas Special [DVD]|work=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.uk]]|date=23 December 2016|accessdate=23 December 2016}}. Series 4 was released on 19 February 2018. {| class="wikitable" style="width:99%; text-align:center;" |- !rowspan="2" colspan="2"|DVD Title !rowspan="2"|No. of Discs !rowspan="2"|Special features !rowspan="2"|No. of Episodes !colspan="2"|Release Dates |- !Region 2 !Region 4 |- | style="background:#96EEA9; width:1px;"| |'''[[Still Open All Hours#Series 1 (2014-15)|Series 1]]''' |1 |2013 Christmas Special |7 |2 February 2015 |24 June 2015 |- | style="background:#008D96; width:1px;"| |'''[[Still Open All Hours#Series 2 (2015-16)|Series 2]]''' |1 |2015 Christmas Special |6 |1 February 2016 | TBA |- | style="background:#BC73FF; width:1px;"| |'''[[Still Open All Hours#Series 3 (2016-17)|Series 3]]''' |1 |2016 Christmas Special |7 |13 February 2017 | TBA |- | style="background:#270487; width:1px;"| | '''[[Still Open All Hours#Series 4 (2017-18)|Series 4]]''' |1 |2017 Christmas Special |7 | 19 February 2018 |TBA |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{BBC programme}} *{{IMDb title|id=3425318|title=Still Open All Hours}} * {{British Comedy Guide|tv|still_open_all_hours}}. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110519111154/http://picasaweb.google.com/lez.briddon/FamousePlacesArkwrightsShop/photo#5087838304152135906 Image of Arkwright's shop in April 2007] {{Open All Hours}} {{Roy Clarke}} [[Category:2010s British sitcoms]] [[Category:2010s British comedy television series]] [[Category:2013 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:BBC high definition programmes]] [[Category:BBC television sitcoms]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Sequel television series]] [[Category:Television series produced at Pinewood Studios]] [[Category:Television series set in shops]] [[Category:Television shows set in South Yorkshire]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> |title = The Last of the Greats |image = TheLastoftheGreats.jpg |imagesize = 160 |caption = cover to issue #1 |schedule = Monthly |ongoing = |Superhero = |publisher = [[Image Comics]] |startmo = October |startyr = 2011 |endmo = February |endyr = 2012 |issues = 5 |main_char_team = Last |writers = [[Joshua Hale Fialkov]] |artists = [[Brent Peeples]] |letterers = |colorists = [[Mirka Andolfo]] |editors = |creators = |subcat = |sort = Last of the Greats }} '''''The Last of the Greats''''' is a comic book [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] created by writer [[Joshua Hale Fialkov]] and artist [[Brent Peeples]]. It was published by [[Image Comics]] from October 5, [[2011 in comics|2011]] through February [[2012 in comics|2012]]. A sequel, ''Return of the Greats'', is forthcoming.<ref>[http://comicattack.net/2012/02/lastofthegreats5 Review of issue 5], Comic Attack. Feb 2012</ref>
==Story== It takes place in a world where seven alien super powered beings known as the ''Greats'' have eliminated disease, poverty, and social inequality. At the start of the story humanity found a way to kill all of the Greats save one, who kept himself hidden,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/comics/last-of-the-greats-interview-fialkov-110928.html |title=Coming Apocalypse? THE LAST OF THE GREATS Doesn't Care |publisher=Newsarama.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref> never bothering to try to help Earth like his siblings did. Now humanity must plead with the last of the Greats to stop an alien invasion that threatens the entire world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=33156 |title=Fialkov is "The Last of the Greats" |publisher=Comic Book Resources |date= |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref>
There are several startling revelations that take place during the first 5 issues of this tale. We find out that though the Greats seemingly died, they are beings of energy and therefore have been absorbed by their remaining brother, who is now extorting the human race into complete subjugation for his help. Next, we find out that when the Last Great seeks to engage the alien ships, he actually goes aboard one of them and seems to be in charge of the fleet, which he then orders 2/3s of the earth's population to be destroyed. In flashbacks we see that the Last Great's sister actually sired a child with her adviser and the child has abilities like the other Greats, but she is being kept hidden from the Last Great for her own protection.
Later in the story, the Last Great is attacked by his "niece", and during the battle, the reader is given a glimpse of the other Greats in a big field under a tree that represents them being part of the Last Great's subconscious, mingling and talking with each other. Due to the Last Great's niece fighting with him, the internal struggle with the other Greats causes them to attempt to release themselves from his body. All of the Greats do this, except for one woman. We then find out that the Last Great and this woman have plotted to have the others release themselves and float around as formless energy so that they can enact a master plan that they have been planning for some time.
==Collected editions== The first series was collected into a [[trade paperback (comics)|trade paperback]]: * ''Volume 1'' (collects ''Last of the Greats'' #1–5, xxx pages, Image Comics, paperback, March 2012, {{ISBN|978-1-60706-518-0}})
==Reception== Jamil Scalese of [[Comics Bulletin]] called the story "page-turning, jaw-dropping" and stated "The Last of the Greats sets itself up to be one the best mindfuck comics to hit shelves recently." He praised the artwork as well.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jason Brice |url=http://www.comicsbulletin.com/reviews/1215/advance-review-the-last-of-the-greats-1/ |title=ADVANCE REVIEW: The Last of the Greats #1 Review - Line of Fire Reviews |publisher=Comics Bulletin |date= |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref> [[IGN]] felt the series had a "neat concept" but complained about the lack of character development in the first issue.<ref>{{cite web|author=Erik Norris |url=http://comics.ign.com/articles/119/1198524p1.html |title=The Last of the Greats #1 Review - Comics Review at IGN |publisher=Comics.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-24}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Comics}} * [[Elk's Run]] * [[I...Vampire#Relaunch|I, Vampire]] * [[Echoes (comics)|Echoes]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.thelastofthegreats.com/ Official website] * [http://www.imagecomics.com/comics/4279/info@imagecomics.com Official page of the publishing company for this comic.] {{DEFAULTSORT:Last Of The Greats}} [[Category:Image Comics limited series]]

'''Tokai Radio Broadcasting. Company Limited''' (東海ラジオ放送株式会社) is a Japanese radio broadcasting company serving the areas of [[Aichi Prefecture]], [[Gifu Prefecture]], and [[Mie Prefecture]], owned by the [[Chunichi Shimbun]] Group.
== Network == * [[National Radio Network (Japan)|NRN (National Radio Network)]]
== Stations == === Aichi Prefecture === * [[Nagoya]] JOSF 1332 kHz 50 kW(STEREO→MONORAL); 92.9 MHz (FM) * Toyohashi JOSM 864 kHz 100 W * Shinshiro 1332 kHz 100 W
=== Gifu Prefecture === * Ena 801 kHz 100 W * Hidakamioka 1458 kHz 100 W * Takayama JOSN 1485kHz 100 W * Gero JOTM 1485 kHz 100 W === Mie Prefecture === * Igaueno 1557 kHz 100 W * Owase 1062 kHz 100 W * Kumano 1485 kHz 100 W
== Programs == * Mid-Night TOKAI(end) * Kanitaku ITTAMONGACHI * Mami RADI cal Communication(end) * Kazuo Zaitu JINSEIGAME-21(end) * Guts Nighter(NighterSeason) etc...
==See also== * [[Tokai Television Broadcasting]]
==External links== * [http://www.tokairadio.co.jp/ Tokai website]
[[Category:Radio in Japan]] [[Category:Media in Nagoya]]
